PT J
AN ZOOR15209055789
DT Article
TI Grassflies of the genus Merochlorops (Diptera: Chloropidae) from
   South-East Asia with description of a new species.
AU Nartshuk, E.P. (chlorops@zin.ru) 
   Liu, X.
   Yang, D.
SO Zoosystematica Rossica
VL 24
IS 2
PS 282-291
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Chloropid flies of the genus Merochlorops Howlett, 1909 (Diptera:
   Chloropidae) from the mainland part of South-East Asia are reviewed. A
   key to determination of nine species is proposed. A new species, M.
   punctifrons, is described from Thailand. The new data on the
   distribution and life mode of larvae are given for other species.
C1 Nartshuk, E.P.; Russian Acad Sci, Inst Zool, 1 Univ Skaya Emb, St
   Petersburg, 199034, Russia, Russia.
EM chlorops@zin.ru
SC Zoology
SN 0320-9180
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones;
   Australasian region; Oriental region; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia;
   Australasia
DE Merochlorops [Asia / mainland South-East Asia / Key to species] [ /
   South-east / Distribution; taxonomic review]. 
   Merochlorops ceylanicus [China /  / New record] [Indonesia /  / ] [Papua
   New Guinea /  / ]. 
   Merochlorops cinctus [Vietnam /  / New record]. 
   Merochlorops lucens [Thailand /  / New record]. 
   Merochlorops punctifrons [Thailand /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Flies
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Diptera, Brachycera, Cyclorrhapha,
   Chloropidae
OR Merochlorops - Howlett 1909 (Chloropidae): [Key to species, Asia,
   mainland South-East Asia, P. 283]. 
   Merochlorops ceylanicus (Chloropidae): [New record]. 
   Merochlorops cinctus (Chloropidae): [New record]. 
   Merochlorops lucens (Chloropidae): [New record]. 
   Merochlorops punctifrons (Chloropidae): [Sp nov, Thailand, Host not
   given, p. 289]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15209055789
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR15209055791
DT Article
TI New species of the genus Parasmittina (Bryozoa: Cheilostomata:
   Smittinidae) from the Chukchi Sea.
AU Denisenko, N.V. (ndenisenko@zin.ru) 
SO Zoosystematica Rossica
VL 24
IS 2
PS 303-306
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the genus Parasmittina Osburn, 19521, P. tatianae sp.
   nov., is described and illustrated. It was obtained from a surface of
   mollusk shells in the south-eastern part of the Chukchi Sea. The new
   species differs from congeners in the size of zooids, in the shapes of
   the primary orifice and peristome and in the morphology of the lyrula
   and the condyles.
C1 Denisenko, N.V.; Russian Acad Sci, Inst Zool, 1 Univ Skaya Emb, St
   Petersburg, 199034, Russia, Russia.
EM ndenisenko@zin.ru
OI Denisenko, Nina/0000-0003-0284-5026
SC Zoology
SN 0320-9180
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Marine zones
DE Parasmittina tatianae [Arctic Ocean /  / New species]. 
TN Bryozoans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Bryozoa
OR Parasmittina tatianae (Bryozoa): [Sp nov, Arctic Ocean, P. 303]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15209055791
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR15208047407
DT Article
TI New contribution to the knowledge of the genus Alloxysta (Insecta:
   Hymenoptera: Cynipoidea: Figitidae): revision of some type material.
AU Ferrer-Suay, M. (mar.ferrer.suay@gmail.com) 
   Selfa, J.
   Pujade-Villar, J.
SO Annalen des Naturhistorischen Museums in Wien Serie B Botanik und
   Zoologie
VL 117
PS 23-36
PD Jan 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The type material of Alloxysta hendrickxi (BENOIT, 1956), Alloxysta
   marshalliana (KIEFFER, 1900), Alloxysta quedenfeldti (KIEFFER, 1909) and
   Alloxysta tscheki (GIRAUD, 1860) has been studied. These species are
   considered valid, and are described completely and illustrated here,
   with some considerations to A. tscheki. Alloxysta maxima HEDICKE, 1914
   is here synonymized with Alloxysta pallidicornis (CURTIS, 1838).
   Alloxysta filimentosus ANDREWS, 1978 and Alloxysta ullrichi (GIRAUD,
   1860) are considered as nomina dubia until type material is found and
   studied.
C1 Ferrer-Suay, M.; Univ Barcelona, Fac Biol, Avda Diagonal 645, Barcelona,
   E-08028, Spain, Spain.
EM mar.ferrer.suay@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 0255-0105
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Type material; Description; Synonymy;
   Available name; Taxonomy
TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hymenoptera, Apocrita, Terebrantia,
   Cynipoidea, Cynipidae
OR Alloxysta - Foerster 1869 (Cynipidae): [Revision, P. 23]. 
   Alloxysta filimentosus - Andrews 1978 (Cynipidae): [Nomen dubium, P.
   25]. 
   Alloxysta hendrickxi - (Benoit 1956) (Cynipidae): [Redescription,
   Female, p. 25; Status, Valid species, p. 23]. 
   Alloxysta marshalliana - (Kieffer 1900) (Cynipidae): [Redescription,
   Male, p. 27; Status, Valid species, p. 23]. 
   Alloxysta maxima - Hedicke 1914 (Cynipidae): [Lectotype designated, P.
   29; Redescription, Male, p. 29]. 
   Alloxysta pallidicornis - (Curtis 1838) (Cynipidae): [Syn nov, Alloxysta
   maxima Hedicke 1914, p. 29]. 
   Alloxysta quedenfeldti - (Kieffer 1909) (Cynipidae): [Redescription,
   Male, p. 29; Status, Valid species, p. 23]. 
   Alloxysta tscheki - (Giraud 1860) (Cynipidae): [Redescription, P. 32;
   Status, Valid species, p. 23]. 
   Alloxysta ullrichi - (Giraud 1860) (Cynipidae): [Nomen dubium, P. 34]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15208047407
DA 2020-09-17

DT Article
TI Review of the genus Monteira Melichar, 1906 with a new species from
   Namibia (Hemiptera: Fulgoromorpha: Nogodinidae).
AU Constant, Jerome (jerome.constant@naturalsciences.be) 
SO Belgian Journal of Entomology
VL 31
PS 3-14
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The species of the genus Monteira Melichar, 1906 (Nogodinidae) are
   illustrated and keyed. A new species, M. ameliae sp. nov. is described
   from the Kuzikus Wildlife Reserve in the Namibian Kalahari and compared
   with the three species hitherto described in the genus. Male genitalia
   of M. ameliae sp. nov. are figured. A distribution map for the four
   species of the genus is provided.
C1 Constant, Jerome; Royal Belgian Inst Nat Sci, OD Phylogeny & Taxon,
   Vautier St 29, Brussels, B-1000, Belgium, Belgium.
EM jerome.constant@naturalsciences.be

   Afrotropical region; Africa

   Monteira ameliae [Namibia /  / New species].

PT J

DT Article
TI COMMUNITY OF ENDOHELMINTH PARASITES OF YELLOWMOUTH BLENNY LABRISOMUS
   PHILIPPII (STEINDACHNER, 1866) (PERCIFORMES: LABRISOMIDAE) FROM THE
   CENTRAL COAST OF PERU.
FT Comunidad de endohelmintos parasitos del trambollo de boca amarilla
   LABRISOMUS PHILIPPII (steindachner, 1866) (perciformes: LABRISOMIDAE) de
   la costa CENTRAL del PERU.
AU Cruces, Celso (celso_rdt10@hotmail.com) 
   Chero, Jhon
   Iannacone, Jose
   Saez, Gloria
   Alvarino, Lorena
SO Biologist - Lima
VL 13
IS 1
PS 91-109
PD Jan 2015
PY 2015
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 2
AB At present there are few studies related to the ecological aspects of
   macroparasites of labrisomid hosts from South America; most involve
   qualitative aspects and breadth of scope. The aim of this study was to
   evaluate the community of endohelminth parasites in yellowmouth blenny
   Labrisomus philippii (Labrisomidae) from the central coast of Peru. L.
   philippii specimens were acquired from the Artisanal Fisheries Wharf,
   Chorrillos, Lima, Peru and were examined using standardized procedures
   of parasitology. The average species richness was 1.59 (0-4). Five hosts
   (17.24%) showed infection with any parasite. Of the parasites found,
   84.51% were adult forms of gastrointestinal helminths and 15.49% larval
   forms. Trematodes corresponded to Lecithochirium macrorchis
   (Hemiuridae), Zoogonus dextrocirrus (Zoogonidae), Prosorhynchoides
   carvajali (Bucephalidae) and Bucephalus sp. (Bucephalidae). The
   tapeworms collected belonged to Lacistorhynchus tenuis
   (Lacistorhynchidae). Nematodes were identified as Proleptus carvajali
   (Physalopteridae). The acanthocephalans corresponded to Corynosoma
   australe (Polymorphidae) and Profilicollis altmani (Polymorphidae). The
   two parasites with highest specific importance (average prevalence and
   abundance) were L. macrorchis and Z. dextrocirrus. Dispersion indexes
   for all parasites showed an aggregated distribution. Only the
   association between prevalence and mean abundance of L. macrorchis with
   host sex was found. Dominance indices showed high values in the parasite
   component community. The dendrogram of similarity showed a group with
   high association among P. altmani, Proleptus carvajali, Bucephalus sp.
   and C. obtuscens. The comparison between the prevalence of parasites L.
   philippii during 1988, 2008 and 2012 on the central coast of Peru showed
   significant differences between years, not registering the same taxa in
   the community component of L. philippii. Lecithochirium macrorchis,
   Zoogonus dextrocirrus and Prosorhynchoides carvajali are new records for
   L. philippii and for Peru.
C1 Cruces, Celso; UNFV, Lab Parasitol, Lima, Peru, Peru.
EM celso_rdt10@hotmail.com
SC Parasitology; Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 1816-0719; 1994-9073
BD Parasites diseases and disorders; Parasites; Hosts; Ecology; Land zones;
   Neotropical region; South America
DE Acanthocephala; Nematoda; Platyhelminthes [Piscean hosts / Labrisomus
   philippii / Host parasite list; prevalence; distribution] [Peru /
   Central coast / ]. 
   Labrisomus philippii [Helminth parasites /  / Host parasite list;
   prevalence; distribution] [Ecology /  / ] [Peru / Central coast / ]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Invertebrates; Nematodes; Platyhelminths; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Perciformes, Labrisomidae
OR Acanthocephala (Animalia): [Parasite]. 
   Nematoda (Animalia): [Parasite]. 
   Platyhelminthes (Animalia): [Parasite]. 
   Labrisomus philippii (Labrisomidae): [Host].

DT Article
TI ONE NEW SPECIES OF THE SUBGENUS ERIOCERA MACQUART FROM CHINA (DIPTERA:
   LIMONIIDAE).
AU Men, Qiulei (menqiulei888@126.com) 
SO Entomologica Americana
VL 121
IS 1-4
PS 10-12
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB During a taxonomic study on crane fly specimens from Liankangshan
   National Nature Reserve, Henan Province, China, three male specimens of
   the subgenus Eriocera were found to represent a new species, which was
   named Hexatoma (Eriocera) macrotuberculata sp. nov. This is the second
   species of the subgenus Eriocera known to be distributed in Henan
   Province, China. The new species is illustrated and described. The type
   specimens of the new species are deposited in Anqing Normal University,
   Anqing, Anhui Province, China.
C1 Men, Qiulei; Anqing Normal Univ, Sch Life Sci, Anqing, Anhui, 246011,
   China, China.

AB The genus Telostholus Haupt (Pompilidae: Pompilinae) from China is
   reviewed and a key to the world species is provided. Three new species,
   T. verticitumidus Li and Li, sp. n. and T. nontuberatus Li and Ma, sp.
   n. from Yunnan, China, and T. alobscuratus Li and Ma, sp. n. from
   Shanxi, China, are described and illustrated.

DT Article
TI TAXONOMIC NOTES ON VESPINAE (HYMENOPTERA: VESPIDAE).
AU Carpenter, James M. (carpente@amnh.org) 
   Kojima, Jun-Ichi
   Dvorak, Libor
   Perrard, Adrien
SO Entomologica Americana
VL 121
IS 1-4
PS 35-37
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 1
U2 6
AB Taxonomic notes are provided for several taxa of Vespinae. Vespula
   austriaca (Panzer, 1799) and Vespula infernalis (de Saussure, 1854) can
   be distinguished by the sculpturing on the frons in the queen. Vespula
   yunlongensis Dong and Wang, 2003, is a synonym of V. flaviceps (Smith,
   1870), NEW SYNONYMY, while V. yulongensis Dong and Wang, 2002, is not a
   synonym of that species, but of V. rufa (Linnaeus, 1758), NEW SYNONYMY.
   The type of Vespa peruana de Saussure, 1867, has been found in Geneva,
   and the species is confirmed as a synonym of Dolichovespula norwegica
   (Fabricius, 1781). Vespula shinanoensis Takamizawa, 2005, is a nomen
   nudum.
C1 Carpenter, James M.; Amer Museum Nat Hist, Div Invertebrate Zool, New
   York, NY, 10024, USA, USA.
EM carpente@amnh.org
OI Perrard, Adrien/0000-0002-4279-9987
SC Zoology
SN 1947-5136; 1947-5144
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Synonymy; Unavailable name
TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hymenoptera, Apocrita, Aculeata,
   Vespoidea, Vespidae
OR Dolichovespula norwegica - (Fabricius 1781) (Vespidae): [Senior synonym,
   Of Vespa peruana de Saussure 1867, p. 36]. 
   Vespa peruana - de Saussure 1867 (Vespidae): [Junior synonym, Of
   Dolichovespula norwegica (Fabricius 1781), p. 36]. 
   Vespula flaviceps - Smith 1870 (Vespidae): [Syn nov, Vespula
   yunlongensis Dong & Wang 2003, p. 35]. 
   Vespula rufa - Linnaeus 1758 (Vespidae): [Syn nov, Vespula yulongensis
   Dong & Wang 2002, p. 36]. 
   Vespula shinanoensis - Takamizawa 2005 (Vespidae): [Nomen nudum, P. 37].

AB Four new species (Trigoniophthalmus lermontovi sp. n., T. borgustani sp.
   n., Allopsontus borgustani sp. n., Silvestrichilis caucasica sp. n.) and
   a new subgenus Anisoptinus subgen. n. in the genus Allopsontus are
   described from the Caucasus, and three new species (Allopsontus
   tekelensis sp. n., A. verae, sp. n., A. saryozeki sp. n.) are described
   from Southeastern Kazakhstan. A key to 16 described species of the genus
   Silvestrichilis is given.

TI A SUBGENERIC SUBDIVISION OF THE GENUS CALISCELIS LAP. WITH DESCRIPTION
   OF NEW SPECIES (HOMOPTERA, CALISCELIDAE).
FT Podrodovoe delenie roda CALISCELIS LAP. s opisaniem nvyh vidov
   (HOMOPTERA, CALISCELIDAE).
AU Emeljanov, A.F. (hemipt@zin.ru) 
SO Entomologicheskoe Obozrenie
VL 94
IS 3
PS 684-697
PD 2015
PY 2015
NT Serial normally translated cover to cover in: Entomological Review.
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB Genus Caliscelis Laporte is subdivided into 5 subgenera Caliscelis s.
   str. (type species C. heterodoxa Lap.), Bambula subgen. n. (type species
   C. wallengreni Stal), Caurca subgen. n. (type species C. gissarica
   Kuzn.), Cerepa subgen. n. (type species C. carnavalis sp. n.), and
   Melanero subgen. n. (type species C. nero Fennah). New species are
   described as following: Caliscelis (s. str.) ephippiata sp. n. (Iranian
   Kurdistan), C. (Bambula) turbata sp. n. (Uzbekistan), C. (Cerepa)
   carnavalis sp. n. (Vietnam, Laos), C. (Cerepa) gnezdilovi sp. n.
   (Vietnam), and C. (Melanero) larvata sp. n. (IOAP). Caliscelis
   triplicata Che, Wang et Zhang is placed to synonymy of C. wallengreni
   Stal, 1863 (= triplicata Che, Wang et Zhang, 2011, syn. n.). Keys to
   subgenera (based on the male characters) and to species of Caliscelis
   Laporte from Russia and adjacent countries are given.

DT Article
TI COMPOSITION OF THE SUBFAMILY PERIACMINAE (LEPIDOPTERA, LYPUSIDAE) WITH
   DESCRIPTIONS OF NEW AND LITTLE KNOWN SPECIES OF THE GENUS MELEONOMA
   MEYRICK, 1914 FROM SOUTH, EAST AND SOUTH-EAST ASIA.
FT Struktura podsem. PERIACMINAE (LEPIDOPTERA, LYPUSIDAE) i opisanie novyh
   i maloizvestnyh vidov roda MELEONOMA MEYRICK, 1914 iz Yuzhnoi,
   Vostochnoi i Yugo-Vostochnoi Azii.
AU Lvovsky, A.L. (Alexander.Lvovsky@zin.ru) 
SO Entomologicheskoe Obozrenie
VL 94
IS 3
PS 705-718
PD 2015
PY 2015
NT Serial normally translated cover to cover in: Entomological Review.
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 3
AB The subfamily Periacminae is characterized by the structure of the valva
   narrowed at the base, with sacculus sharply separated from the rest part
   of the valva. The subfamily includes two tribes: Periacmini Lvovsky,
   2005 (with four genera: Periacma Meyrick, 1894; Irepacma Moriuti, Saito
   et Lewvanich, 1985; Ripeacma Moriuti, Saito et Lewvanich, 1985, and
   Epiracma Wang et Li, 2005) and Meleonomini Lvovsky, trib. n. with two
   genera Meleonoma Meyrick, 1914 and Phaulolechia Diakonoff, 1951. A key
   to genera based on the characters of the moths' appearance and genitalia
   is provided. The following new synonymy is established: Meleonoma
   Meyrick, 1914 (= Acryptolechia Lvovsky, 2010, syn. n.), and Phaulolechia
   Diakonoff, 1951 (= Variacma Wang, 2006, syn. n.). Four new species of
   Meleonoma are described from Nepal: M. nepalella sp. n., M. jubingella
   sp. n., M. dierli sp. n., M. montana sp. n.; and M. meyricki sp. n. is
   described from China. Eight new combinations are established: Meleonoma
   malacobyrsa (Meyrick, 1921) comb. n., Meleonoma facunda (Meyrick, 1910),
   comb. n., Meleonoma torophanes (Meyrick, 1935), comb. n. (all from
   Acryptolechia), Meleonoma flavimaculata (Christoph, 1882), comb. n.
   (from Euteles), Meleonoma peditata (Wang, 2006), comb. n. (from
   Cryptolechia), Phaulolechia saccata (Wang, 2006), comb. n., Phaulolechia
   subrotunda (Wang, 2006), comb. n. and Phaulolechia isotyra (Meyrick,
   1938), comb. n. (all from Variacma). Meleonoma facialis Li et Wang, 2002
   originally described from China is discovered in the Russian Far East,
   Nepal and Indonesia (Java).
C1 Lvovsky, A.L.; Russian Acad Sci, Inst Zool, Univ Skaya Nabarezhnaya 1,
   St Petersburg, 199034, Russia, Russia.
EM Alexander.Lvovsky@zin.ru
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Reproductive Biology

   Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Key; General morphology; Reproduction;
   Reproductive system; Land zones; Oriental region; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia; China

   nepalella [Nepal /  / New species].

OR Meleonoma - Meyrick 1914 (Cosmopterigidae): [Designated type genus for
   new tribe, Meleonomini, p. 709; Senior synonym, Of Acryptolechia Lvovsky
   2010, p. 711]. 
   Meleonoma dierli (Cosmopterigidae): [Sp nov, Nepal, P. 714]. 
   Meleonoma facialis (Cosmopterigidae): [New record]. 
   Meleonoma facunda - (Meyrick 1910) (Cosmopterigidae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Acryptolechia, p. 711]. 
   Meleonoma flavimaculata - (Christoph 1882) (Cosmopterigidae): [Comb nov,

TI RARE GALL-MIDGE GENERA PLUTODIPLOSIS GROVER ET BAKHSHI AND TRIOMMATOMYIA
   MAMAEV (DIPTERA, CECIDOMYIIDAE: LESTODIPLOSIDI STAT. N., APHIDOLETIDI)
   WITH DESCRIPTIONS OF A NEW AND A LITTLE KNOWN SPECIES FROM SOUTHERN
   PRIMORYE AREA.
FT Redkiye rody gallits PLUTODIPLOSIS GROVER ET BAKHSHI i TRIOMMATOMYIA
   MAMAEV (DIPTERA, CECIDOMYIIDAE: LESTODIPLOSIDI STAT. N., APHIDOLETIDI) i
   opisaniye novogo i maloizvestnogo vidov iz Yuzhnogo Primor'ya.
AU Fedotova, Z.A. (zoya-fedotova@mail.ru) 
SO Entomologicheskoe Obozrenie
VL 94
IS 3
PS 719-738
PD 2015
PY 2015
NT Serial normally translated cover to cover in: Entomological Review.
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB Systematic positions of a new for the Russian fauna genus
   Plutodiplosisis belonging to the supertribe Lestodiplosidi, stat. n. and
   a rare genus Triommatomyia (Aphidoletidi (Aphidoletini)) are updated.
   The two genera are similar in having strongly prolonged sensorial loops
   of male flagellomeres. The diagnoses for Aphidoletidi and Lestodiplosidi
   are supplemented. Genus Plutodiplosis is new to the Russian fauna and
   includes 5 species: P. heterofila, P. magnifica, P. testa sp. n., P.
   raphani (Barnes), comb. n. (from Lestodiplosis) and P. venusta (Gagne),
   comb. n. (from Lestodiplosis). Genus Triommatomyia includes two species,
   T. barnesi and T. papillata; a supplemented description of the latter is
   given. Keys to the species of the genera Plutodiplosis and Triommatomyia
   are given.

   196608, Russia, Russia.

DT Article
TI New data to the Middle Triassic stratigraphy of the Balaton Highland
   (Hungary).
FT Uj adatok a Balaton-felvidek kozepso-triasz retegtanahoz.
AU Voros, Attila
   Tamas, Karoly
   Budai, Tamas
SO Foldtani Kozlony
VL 145
IS 4
PS 315-324
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA Hungarian
U1 0
U2 0
AB K. TAMAS and his wife G. FOLDVARI, spent decades fossil hunting in the
   Balaton Highland region and in the process gathered a large collection
   of Triassic ammonoids; these are now housed in Kovagoors (Veszprem
   county). The most beautiful examples from this collection warrant a
   publication devoted solely to themselves. On the other hand, some of the
   ammonoids, especially those from Szentkiralyszabadja and Szentbekkalla,
   are also worth careful examination due to their considerable scientific
   (mainly palaeontological and stratigraphical) importance. This paper
   presents short reports and illustrations of eleven ammonoid specimens,
   selected according to the above points of view. Besides the
   palaeontological data, the new collecting work and other field
   observations brought new stratigraphical results. The poor exposures in
   the Szentbekkalla vineyards, along with the earlier results of
   geological mapping and new ammonoid findings, provide evidence showing a
   continuous series of Anisian to Ladinian formations of basin facies.
   They represent the most westward lying occurrences of these formations
   in the Balaton Highland. The geological cross-section drawn between
   Farkas Hill and Kelemen Cliff reveals the south-eastward dipping series
   of the Megyehegy Formation, the Felsoors Formation, the Vaszoly
   Formation (Anisian), and both members (Nemesvamos and Keresztfateto
   Members) of the Buchenstein Formation (Ladinian). This complex of
   formations forms the NW limb of a local syncline which strikes parallel
   with the Liter overthrust, on the northern side of this major tectonic
   line. The newly collected ammonoids (Kellnerites cf. bosnensis, N. gen.
   aff. Kellnerites bagolinensis, Reitziites reitzi, R. cholnokyi,
   Latemarites latemarensis) complete "missing parts" of the
   biostratigraphical units known previously in the Szentbekkalla locality
   and thus prove conclusively all four subzones (Felsoeoersensis,
   Liepoldti, Reitzi, Avisianum) of the Reitzi Zone. Several pieces of the
   Proarcestes sp. found in the scree of Nemesvamos Limestone (Buchenstein
   Formation) hint at the presence of the Ladinian Curionii Zone. The
   previously described section of Szentkiralyszabadja was completed
   upsection with two fossiliferous layers, revealed by new excavations and
   fossil collections. The newly exposed beds - like the deeper, major part
   of the section - represent an unusual (partly dolomitic, less siliceous)
   facies of the Vaszoly Formation. The uppermost (No. -2) bed yielded a
   specimen of Ticinites cf. crassus, thus proving the Crassus Subzone of
   the Secedensis Zone, whereas the other specimen figured here
   (Nevaditessp.) underscores the presence of the Secedensis Zone in the
   Szentkiralyszabadja section.
C1 Voros, Attila; Magyar Termeszettudomanyi Muzeum, Oslenytani es Foldtani
   Tar, 1431 Budapest, Pf. 137., 28254 Kovagoors, Kossuth u. 44, Hungary,
   Hungary.
SC Paleontology; Zoology
SN 0015-542X
BD Ecology; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological
   time periods; Mesozoic
DE Ammonoidea [Fossil assemblages /  / New record; taxonomic implications]
   [Hungary / Balaton Highland / stratigraphical distribution] [Triassic /
   Middle Triassic / ]. 
   Kellnerites bagolinensis; Latemarites latemarensis; Reitziites
   cholnokyi; Reitziites reitzi [Hungary / Balaton Highland / new record;
   stratigraphical distribution] [Triassic / Middle Triassic / ]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Cephalopoda, Ammonoidea, Ceratitida
OR Ammonoidea (Cephalopoda): [Fossil; New record]. 
   Kellnerites bagolinensis (Ceratitida): [Fossil; New record]. 
   Latemarites latemarensis (Ceratitida): [Fossil; New record]. 
   Reitziites cholnokyi (Ceratitida): [Fossil; New record]. 
   Reitziites reitzi (Ceratitida): [Fossil; New record].

DT Article
TI Fish diversity and composition from San Pedro river, Balancan, Tabasco,
   Mexico.
FT Composicion y diversidad de peces del rio San Pedro, Balancan, Tabasco,
   Mexico.
AU Castillo-Dominguez, Alfonso (alfonso.castillo@ujat.mx) 
   Esther Melgar-Valdes, Carolina
   Barba Macias, Everardo
   Rodiles-Hernandez, Roco
   de Jesus Navarrete, Alberto
   Perera Garcia, Martha Alicia
   Cuenca Soria, Carlos A.
   Hernandez Gomez, Raul E.
SO Hidrobiologica
VL 25
IS 2
PS 285-292
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 16
AB In the San Pedro river sub-basin, Balancan, Tabasco, Mexico, an
   ichthyofauna study was carried out in two subsystems; the main stream
   and the floodplain during the months of March 2007 to February 2008.
   From a total of 1035 fish were collected, 33 species, 25 genera and 14
   families were identified. The Cichlidae and Poeciliidae family were the
   most species; four species are introduced Pterygoplichthys pardalis,
   Ctenopharyngodon idella, Oreochromis niloticus, Parachromis managuensis
   and two new records were found: P. pardalis and Potamarius usumacintae.
   The most abundance species were Thorichthys affinis and T. helleri and
   five species were least abundant: P. usumacintae, Phallichthys
   fairweatheri, "Cichlasoma" Nandopsis urophthalmus, C. idella and
   Batrachoides goldmani. The higher values of diversity and abundance
   showed in sites I (H'=2.52 bits) and II ([lambda]=0.38 sp/ind). The
   higher values of evenness were in sites III (J'=0.86) and IV (J'=0.99).
   The abundance (Nmax=353) species was showed in the site II. Significant
   differences (p<0.05) were found between the diversity and sites
   comparison. Canonical correspondence analysis showed that the
   temperature, dissolved oxygen and depth are the most important factors
   in the distribution of species. Finally, the relative abundance of
   species in the two seasons was representative by two families; Cichlidae
   T. affinis, (T. helleri and Petenia splendida) and Characidae (Astyanax
   aeneus).
C1 Castillo-Dominguez, Alfonso; UJAT, Div Acad Multidisciplinaria Rios, Km
   1 Carretera Tenosique Estapilla, Tenosique, Tabasco, 86901, Mexico,
   Mexico.
EM alfonso.castillo@ujat.mx
RI BARBA MACIAS, EVERARDO/A-9154-2015; de Jesus Navarrete,
   Alberto/X-9763-2019; Castillo Dominguez, Alfonso/S-3063-2016
OI BARBA MACIAS, EVERARDO/0000-0001-7263-8941; Castillo Dominguez,
   Alfonso/0000-0002-2247-953X
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology; Marine &Freshwater Biology
SN 0188-8897
BD Ecology; Habitat; Freshwater habitat; Lotic water; Land zones; Nearctic
   region; North America

   Tabasco, Balancan, San Pedro river / ]. 
   Potamarius usumacintae; Pterygoplichthys pardalis [Mexico / Tabasco,
   Balancan, San Pedro river / New record]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates

   Siluriformes, Ariidae, Loricariidae
OR Pisces (Vertebrata).

   Pterygoplichthys pardalis (Loricariidae): [New record].

TI Aleocharinae from New Zealand collected by Dr. PM Giachino and Dr. M.
   Daccordi. (Coleoptera, Staphylinidae).
FT Aleocharinae della Nuova Zelanda, raccolte dal Dr. P.M. Giachino e dal
   Dr. M. Daccordi (Coleoptera, Staphylinidae).
AU Pace, Roberto (pace.ent@tiscali.it) 
SO Museo Regionale di Scienze Naturali Bollettino (Turin)
VL 32
IS 1-2
PS 125-152
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 1
AB A taxonomic study of the Staphylinidae subfamily Aleocharinae of the
   north New Zealand is presented. Seven tribes (Pronomaeini, Gyrophaenini,
   Homalotini, Bolitocharini, Falagriini, Athetini, Oxypodini), nineteen
   genera (Myllaena, Notiomerinx, Coenonica, Makrosolenia, Falagria,
   Kompsatele, Dasytricheta, Ecomorypora, Amischa, Aztstraloconota,
   Geostibasoma, Leptostiba, Neozealatheta, Pelioptera, Neozelandusa,
   Pronomaeida, Thrixenglyphe, Calodera, Neodoxa) and 27 species are
   recognized. Five genera (Makrosolenia of the Bolitocharini Kompsatele of
   the Falagriini, Neozealatheta of the Athetini, Pronomaeida and
   Thrixenglyphe of the Oxypodini) and 20 species (Myllaena tangarakauensis
   n. sp., Coenonica neozealandensis n. sp., Makrosolenia neozealandensis
   n. sp., Falagria neozealandicola n. sp., Kompsatele neozealandense n.
   sp., Ecomorypora tongarirensis n. sp., Ecomorypora daccordii n. sp.,
   Amischa neozealandensis n. sp., Australoconota neozealandensis n. sp.,
   Geostibasoma neozealandensis n. sp., Leptostiba minor n. sp.,
   Neozealatheta urewerensis n. sp., Pelioptera eruensis n. sp.,
   Neozelandusa ruapehumontis n. sp., Pronomaeida pectinis n. sp.,
   Pronomaeida giachinoi n. sp., Thrixenglyphe neozealandense n. sp.,
   Calodera neozealandensis n. sp., Neodoxa tongarirensis n. sp., Neodoxa
   tapuensis n. sp.) are described as new to the science. New combinations
   is proposed for 1 species of the Oxypodini. Each new genus and species
   is described, compared and illustrated.

DT Article
TI Aleocharinae (Coleoptera, Staphylinidae) from Australia collected by Dr.
   PM Giachino.
FT Aleocharinae dell' Australia raccolte dal Dr. P.M. Giachino (Coleoptera,
   Staphylinidae).
AU Pace, Roberto (pace.ent@tiscali.it) 
SO Museo Regionale di Scienze Naturali Bollettino (Turin)
VL 32
IS 1-2
PS 153-164
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 0
AB A taxonomic study of the Staphylinid subfamily Aleocharinae of the
   Western Australia is presented. Two tribes (Athetini, Lomechusini), 5
   genera (Leptostiba, Atheta, Pelioptera, Ischyrodyodoys, Australiacantha)
   and 7 species are recognized. The genus Australiacantha of the tribe
   Lomechusini and 5 species (Leptostiba bigladifera n. sp., Leptostiba
   karijiniensis n. sp., Atheta (Acrotona) stirlingensis n. sp., Pelioptera
   stirlingicola n. sp., Australiacantha stirlingensis n. sp.) are
   described as new to the science. The new genus and new species are
   described and illustrated.

TI New silverfish species (Zygentoma: Lepismatidae) from Barrow Island.

AB Three new species of the subfamily Ctenolepismatinae (Qantelsella
   maculosa sp. nov., Q. aurantia sp. nov. and Acrotelsella transpectinata
   sp. nov.) and one of the subfamily Lepismatinae (Xenolepisma perexiguum
   sp. nov.) are described from Barrow Island. Keys are provided for the
   described species of Qantelsella Smith and Xenolepisma Mendes.

TI A new troglobitic schizomid (Hubbardiidae: Paradraculoides) from the
   Pilbara region, Western Australia.
AU Abrams, Kym M.
   Harvey, Mark S.
SO Records of the Western Australian Museum
VL 30
IS 2
PS 132-136
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of Hubbardiidae, Paradraculoides eremius sp. nov., is
   described from Bungaroo, Pilbara, Western Australia based on male and
   female specimens collected from troglofauna traps. Although similar in
   form to other Paradraculoides known from the Pilbara bioregion, it has a
   distinctive male flagellum which is distally rounded rather than
   tapering to a point as in other species. It is known from only a small
   area of less than 10 km2 in the Hamersley Range.

SO Records of the Western Australian Museum
VL 30
IS 2
PS 144-150
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the peacock spider genus Maratus, M. proszynskii, is
   described from north-eastern Tasmania, Australia. This species appears
   most similar to M. velutinus Otto and Hill, 2012, and brings to four the
   number of described species of Maratus known from Tasmania: M. pavonis
   (Dunn, 1947), M. harrisi Otto and Hill 2011, M. tasmanicus Otto and Hill
   2013, and M. proszynskii sp. nov.

DT Article
TI A revision of the genus Calicnemis Laporte, 1832 (Coleoptera,
   Scarabaeidae, Dynastinae).
FT Revision del genero Calicnemis Laporte, 1832 : enfoques morfologico y
   genetic Revision du genre Calicnemis Laporte, 1832: approche
   morphologique et genetique (Coleoptera, Scarabaeidae, Dynastinae).
AU Verdugo, Antonio
   Drumont, Alain
SO Revue de l'Association Roussillonnaise d'Entomologie
VL 24
SU S
PS 1-64
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA French; Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus Calicnemis includes species restricted to the sandy beaches of
   the Atlantic coast and the western part of the Mediterranean. The
   habitus of many specimens of all taxa, including all types and all
   escamined localities for each taxon is illustrated. Data on the
   morphology of eggs and larvae, on the natural history and the ecology of
   this genus also provided. In addition, a key to the taxa, and a
   comprehensive list of publications of the genus Calicnemis are proposed.
   In this revision, we have combined a classic morphological study with a
   genetic analysis involving DNA barcoding to identify unequivocally the
   existence of three different taxa within the genus Calicnemis. After the
   combination of these two complementary studies, we are able to establish
   that the genus Calicnemis is composed of two species, C. latreillei
   Laporte, 1832 and C. obesa (Erichson, 1841), the latter being composed
   of two sub-species, the nominotypical subspecies one and C. obesa
   sardiniensis Leo, 1985 comb. nov.. We confirm the spelling Calicnemis
   latreillei Laporte, 1832 to use for the genus and its type-species. Two
   synonymies previously established, Calicnemis atlantica Mosconi, 1996
   and Calicnemis bercedoi Lopez-Colon, 2004 = Calicnemis obesa (Erichson,
   1841), are confirmed. Calicnemis bahilloi Lopez-Colon, 2003 is
   recognized as a new synonym for Calicnemis obesa (Erichson, 1841). A
   neotype is designated for Calicnemis latreillei and a lectotype for
   Colorhinus obesus Erichson, 1841.
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Genetics &Heredity; Environmental Sciences
   &Ecology
SN 1288-5509
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Type material; Synonymy; Unavailable name;
   Taxonomy; Status; Key; Documentation; Publications; General morphology;
   Genetics; Ecology

   morphology /  / ] [Molecular genetics / DNA barcoding / ] [Ecology /  /
   ]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Scarabaeoidea,
   Scarabaeidae
OR Calicnemis - Laporte 1832 (Scarabaeidae): [Revision, P. 1; Spelling, P.
   16; Key to species, P. 59]. 
   Calicnemis atlantica - Mosconi 1996 (Scarabaeidae): [Junior synonym, Of
   Calicnemis obesa (Erichson 1841), p. 58]. 
   Calicnemis bercedoi - Lopez-Colon 2004 (Scarabaeidae): [Junior synonym,
   Of Calicnemis obesa (Erichson 1841), p. 58]. 
   Calicnemis latreillei - Laporte 1832 (Scarabaeidae): [Neotype
   designated, P. 19]. 
   Calicnemis obesa - (Erichson 1841) (Scarabaeidae): [Senior synonym, Of
   Calicnemis atlantica Mosconi 1996, p. 58; Senior synonym, Of Calicnemis
   bercedoi Lopez-Colon 2004, p. 58; Syn nov, Calicnemis bahilloi

   from, Calicnemis sardiniensis, p. 28].

   Calicnemis obesa sardiniensis, p. 28].

   designated, P. 13; Nomen oblitum, P. 13].

   P. 18].

   Authorship, P. 18].

AB Cardiophorinae of Buxa Tiger Reserve, West Bengal, India is monotypic,
   being represented by the only genus Cardiophorus Eschscholtz that
   includes a new species C. ferruginosus and an endemic species C.
   bucculatus Candeze. Both the species are described and illustrated.

   discussed.

PT J
AN ZOOR15208051819
DT Article
TI SPIDER FAUNAL DIVERSITY OF TEA ECOSYSTEM OF ASSAM, INDIA.
AU Saha, Sumana (sahasumana2010@gmail.com) 
   Roy, Tapan Kumar
   Dhali, Dhruba Chandra
   Raychaudhuri, Dinendra
SO Romanian Journal of Biology Zoology
VL 60
IS 1
PS 13-26
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Appreciating the necessity of spiders as bioresource against tea pests,
   the present work unfolds their spectrum in the tea ecosystem of Assam.
   The study area included 4 tea estates, Bukhial T. E., Jamguri T. E.,
   Hunwal T. E. and Kotalgoorie T. E. Altogether 85 species under 53 genera
   distributed over 16 families could be recorded. These can broadly be
   categorized into 7 trophic groups. The decreasing order of the groups
   are Orb weavers (45.88%) > Stalkers (31.76%) > Ground dwellers (18.82%)
   > Foliage hunters (7.05%)> Space weavers (4.70%)> Ambushers (3.52%)>=
   Sheet weavers (3.52%). Two species are considered new to science, 4
   genera and 4 species from the country. Based on the species richness,
   the decreasing order of the tea estates are BTE (61.17%) >= JTE (61.17%)
   > KTE (38.82%) > HTE (35.29%). The present study leads to infer "tea
   system when closer to forests or experiences less pesticides, exhibits
   higher spider heterogeneity". Araneids and salticids are the dominant
   groups. Other than the Oriental representatives, Australian and
   Palaearctic elements are the next major groups. Nearly 38% of the
   species are found to be native.
C1 Saha, Sumana; Govt West Bengal, Darjeeling Govt Coll, Darjeeling, 73410,
   India, India.
EM sahasumana2010@gmail.com
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology
SN 1843-7761
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Ecology; Habitat; Man made habitat;
   Zoogeography; Land zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia; India
DE Araneae [Trophic structure /  / new record; systematics] [Community
   structure /  / ] [Cultivated land habitat / Tea ecosystem / faunal list]
   [Zoogeography / Biogeography / ] [Assam /  / ]. 
   Chalcotropis; Neoscona yptinika; Oxyopes hotingchiehi; Tetragnatha
   hasselti [India /  / New record]. 
   Plexippus levii; Rhene wesolowskai [Assam /  / New species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Araneae

   Oxyopes hotingchiehi (Araneae): [New record]. 
   Plexippus levii (Araneae): [Sp nov, Assam, P. 20].

AN ZOOR15208047574
DT Article
TI [A Female of Lampropelma nigerrimum arboricola ssp n. from Borneo
   (Araneae: Theraphosidae: Ornithoctoninae).]
FT Ein Weibchen von Lampropelma nigerrimum arboricola ssp.n. aus Borneo
   (Araneae: Theraphosidae: Ornithoctoninae).
AU Schmidt, Guenter
   Barensteiner, Ruth
SO Tarantulas of the World
VL 143
PS 4-9
PD Jan 2015
PY 2015
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB Lampropelma nigerrimum arboricola is a subspecies of Lampropelma
   nigerrimum living in Borneo. It is closely related to L. nigerrimum
   nigerrimum SIMON, 1892, the type species of the genus, living on Sangir
   (or Sangihe) Island. An adult female could be studied. It differs from
   the type species in the relative size of the eyes, the spination of the
   legs and the scopula of the fourth metatarsus. The PLE are much smaller
   than the ALE, all legs are spinose and scopula of metatarsus IV is
   present apically in the centre of the segment only. According to
   Jean-Michel VERDEZ the males of both subspecies are different. In L.
   nigerrimum nigerrimum the herringbone pattern on the opisthosoma is
   distinct and the tarsi are not orange, in L. nigerrimum arboricola the
   herringbone pattern on the opisthosoma is absent and the tarsi are
   weakly orange. The new subspecies is dealt under the name L. sp. "Borneo
   black" or Selenocosmia bomeoensis. Both of them are nomina nuda. It is
   said to live arboreously.
SC Zoology
SN 1431-7990
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Oriental region;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Lampropelma nigerrimum arboricola [Asia /  / New subspecies] [Indonesia
   /  / ] [Malaysia /  / ]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Araneae
OR Lampropelma nigerrimum arboricola (Araneae): [Subsp nov, Asia, P. 6].

AN ZOOR15208047578
DT Article
TI [Why Chilocosmia arndsti (SCHMIDT & VON WIRTH, 1992), Chilocosmia
   barensteinerae SCHMIDT, HETTEGGER & MATTHES, 2010, Chilocosmia peerboomi
   SCHMIDT, 1999, Selenopelma kovariki SCHMIDT & KRAUSE, 1995 and Phlogius
   Simon, 1887 (Araneae: Theraphosidae: Selenocosmiinae) not Synonyms of
   Selenocosmia AUSSERER, 1871.]
FT Warum Chilocosmia arndsti (SCHMIDT & VON WIRTH, 1992), Chilocosmia
   barensteinerae SCHMIDT, HETTEGGER & MATTHES, 2010, Chilocosmia peerboomi
   SCHMIDT, 1999, Selenopelma kovariki SCHMIDT & KRAUSE, 1995 und Phlogius
   Simon, 1887 (Araneae: Theraphosidae: Selenocosmiinae) keine Synonyme von
   Selenocosmia AUSSERER, 1871 sind.
AU Schmidt, Guenter
SO Tarantulas of the World
VL 143
PS 32-38
PD Jan 2015
PY 2015
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB According to PLATNICK (2011) Chilocosmia, Phlogius and Selenopelma are
   synonyms of Selenocosmia. He followed the revisions made by RAVEN in
   1985 und 2000. SCHMIDT rejected these synonyms already in 2001. This was
   repeated again in 2003 and also in 2010 especially with reference to
   Chilocosmia. The type species of Selenocosmia, S. javanensis
   (WALCKENAER, 1837), could not be detected in Paris. Probably it has
   disappeared. But there is no doubt that the species which was described
   and copied by AUSSERER (1871), SIMON (1892) and KULCZYNSKI (1908) was
   the same. AUSSERER characterized the female and described the male. He
   portrayed its palp. His type species was Selenocosmia javanensis, the
   only -species known at his time. SIMON (1892) referred to AUSSERER and
   reproduced the stridulating organs of this species in 1903. KULCZYNSKI
   (1908) drew the spermathecae for the first time. In the museum of
   Wiesbaden a female is deposited which KULCZYNSKI identified belonging to
   this species. It could be checked in 1995. All specimens called
   Selenocosmia javanensis which the author could identify had been bought
   in pet shops did really belong to this species. In 1985 RAVEN made a key
   to some genera of Selenocosmiinae. He characterized Selenocosmia by
   absence of peglike setae prolaterally on cheliceral face. But with the
   help of this key it is impossible to identify the type species of this
   genus. It remains absolutely uncertain what kind of "Selenocosmia" he
   had in mind. It has to be said that all true species of Selenocosmia
   have peg like setae prolaterally on cheliceral face. But thanks to his
   erroneous diagnosis of the genus Selenocosmia he had to include in
   Selenocosmia some other genera without such peglike setae like
   Chilocosmia or Phlogius. Even genera such different from Selenocosmia as
   Selenopelma SCHMIDT & KRAUSE, 1995 from Vietnam were included in
   Selenocosmia sensu RAVEN (1985). It would be desirable if the author or
   another competent arachnologist could revise RAVEN'S erroneous diagnosis
   of Selenocosmia and cancel his synonyms with that genus. That could be
   confirmed by genetic investigations. This would possibly be the
   prerequisite for the resurrection of Phlogius and Selenopelma in the
   World Spider Catalog, too. In a recent paper WEST et al. (2012)
   transferred Chilocosmia dichromata SCHMIDT & von WIRTH, 1992 and
   Selenobrachys philippinus SCHMIDT, 1999 to Orphnaecus Simon, 1892 and
   followed RAVEN in his opinion that Haplocosmia himalayana (Pocock,
   1999), Chilocosmia amdsti, Chilocosmia barensteinerae (sp. inc. sed.),
   C. peerboomi and Selenopelma kovariki should be stand for the present in
   the genus Selenocosmia. In my opinion to the last four species new
   genera names are necessary which demonstrate their independence from
   Selenocosmia.
SC Zoology
SN 1431-7990
BD Systematics; Taxonomy
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Araneae
OR Chilocosmia (Araneae): [Status, P. 32]. 
   Phlogius - Simon 1887 (Araneae): [Status, P. 32]. 
   Selenocosmia - Ausserer 1871 (Araneae): [Status, P. 32]. 
   Selenopelma - Schmidt & Krause 1995 (Araneae): [Status, P. 32]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15208047578
DA 2020-09-17
ER

AN ZOOR15208047580

TI [First record of a Selenocosmia insulana subspecies in Borneo (Araneae,

FT Erster Nachweis einer Selenocosmia insulana-Subspezies auf Borneo
   (Araneae, Theraphosidae, Selenocosmiinae), S. insulana borneoensis ssp.
   n.
AU Schmidt, Guenter
SO Tarantulas of the World
VL 143
PS 50-55
PD Jan 2015
PY 2015
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB An adult male of a species genital morphological not distinguishable
   from Selenocosmia insulana HIRST, 1909, could be found the first time in
   Borneo. But it is considerably larger than the species found in Djampea
   and Sulawesi. That is true especially concerning the legs and palps. In
   S. insulana from Djampea the body length is 18 mm, in the subspecies
   from Borneo it is 24 mm. Leg I is in S. insulana 28,5 mm, in the
   subspecies from Borneo it is 48 mm.

DT Article
TI The genus Cosmopterix Hubner of continental Sub-Saharan Africa
   (Lepidoptera: Gelechioidea: Cosmopterigidae).
AU Koster, Sjaak (J.C. ) (sjaak.koster@naturalis.nl) 
SO Tijdschrift voor Entomologie
VL 158
IS 2-3
PS 87-318
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus Cosmopterix Hubner, (1825) of continental Sub-Saharan Africa
   is :revised. A total of 77 species are recognized and 56 species are
   described as new. Of eight new species, all known only from females, the
   validity of the species cannot be confirmed with certainty Four new
   synonyms are proposed. Diagnoses, descriptions, and type information are
   provided for each species. Watercolours of the adults, line drawings of
   the wing venation, the male and the female genitalia and a key to the
   species are included, as well as distribution maps.

PT J
AN ZOOR15208050947
DT Article
TI New data on the family Blaberidae (Dictyoptera) from Southeast Asia: new
   species, morphological diversity and phylogeny on the base of ribosomal
   DNA sequences.
AU Mavropulo, V.A.
   Anisyutkin, L.N. (Leona.Anisyutkin@zin.ru) 
   Zagoskin, M.V.
   Zagoskina, A.S.
   Lukyantsev, S.V.
   Mukha, D.V.
SO Zoosystematica Rossica
VL 24
IS 1
PS 14-30
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 1
U2 2
AB New cockroaches of the family Blaberidae are described from Southern
   Sumatra: two new species of the genus Cyrtonotula Uvarov, 1939, C.
   secunda sp. nov. and C. tertia sp. nov. (Epilamprinae); and one new
   species of the genus Paranauphoeta J.W.H. Rehn, 1951, P. pullata sp.
   nov. (Paranauphoetinae). Detailed morphological descriptions of the new
   species are given. Structures of the male genitalia of the genus
   Cyrtonotula are described for the first time. Hypothesis on the
   relationships of these new taxa as well as Morphna maculata Brunner von
   Wattenwyl, 1865, Rhabdoblatta sp. and Pseudophoraspis sp. based on 28S
   ribosomal DNA sequences is discussed.
C1 Anisyutkin, L.N.; Russian Acad Sci, Inst Zool, 1 Univ Skaya Emb, St
   Petersburg, 199034, Russia, Russia.
EM Leona.Anisyutkin@zin.ru
OI Mukha, Dmitry/0000-0002-7380-0776
SC Zoology; Genetics &Heredity; Evolutionary Biology
SN 0320-9180
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Genetics; Evolution;
   Variation; Land zones; Oriental region; Palaearctic region; Eurasia;
   Asia
DE Blaberidae [Molecular genetics / rDNA sequences / systematics]
   [Phylogeny /  / ] [Morphological variation /  / ] [Asia / Southeast /
   distribution]. 
   Cyrtonotula secunda; Cyrtonotula tertia; Paranauphoeta pullata
   [Indonesia /  / New species].

ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Dictyoptera, Blattodea

AN ZOOR15208050949
DT Article
TI New data on the genus Peracca (Orthoptera: Tettigoniidae:
   Conocephalinae) in Malaysia, with description of two new species.
AU Gorochov, A.V. (orthopt@zin.ru) 
SO Zoosystematica Rossica
VL 24
IS 1
PS 42-47
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Peracca omissa sp. nov. and P. derelicta sp. nov. from western part of
   Malaysia are described. These species are very similar to P.
   conspicuithorax Griffini, 1897 and P. mirzai Tan et Ingrisch, 2014 but
   differs from them in the shape of some male abdominal structures.
   Peracca macritchiensis Tan et Ingrisch, 2014, syn. nov. from Singapore
   is synonymized to P. tiomani Gorochov, 2011 described from Tioman I.
   near southern part of Malacca Peninsula.
C1 Gorochov, A.V.; Russian Acad Sci, Inst Zool, 1 Univ Skaya Emb, St
   Petersburg, 199034, Russia, Russia.
EM orthopt@zin.ru
SC Zoology
SN 0320-9180

   region; Eurasia; Asia

   species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Orthoptera, Saltatoria

DT Article
TI New and little-known taxa of the tribe Diestramimini (Orthoptera:
   Rhaphidophoridae: Aemodogryllinae) from Southeast Asia. Part 1.
AU Gorochov, A.V. (orthopt@zin.ru) 
   Storozhenko, S. Yu.
SO Zoosystematica Rossica
VL 24
IS 1
PS 48-84
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new subgenus, 19 new species and two new subspecies are described from
   Vietnam, Laos and China: Tamdaotettix (Tamdaotettix) aculeatus sp. nov.,
   T (T.) flexus sp. nov., T (T.) laocai sp. nov., T. (Laotettix subgen.
   nov.) tarasovi sp. nov., T (L.) curvatus sp. nov., T. (L.) minutus sp.
   nov., T (L.) inflatus sp. nov., T (L.) sympatricus sp. nov., T. (?)
   robustus sp. nov., Gigantettix laosensis sp. nov., G. maximus auster
   subsp. nov., Diestramima hainanensis sp. nov., D. bispinosa sp. nov., D.
   hamata sp. nov., D. propria sp. nov., D. yunnanensis sp. nov., D.
   champasak sp. nov., Adiestramima adunca sp. nov., A. bella sp. nov., A.
   elongata sp. nov., A. perfecta hue subsp. nov. Previously unknown male
   of G. maximus maximus Gorochov, 1998 and imago of D. palpata (Rehn,
   1906) are described on the base of a new material. New distributional
   data for some species are given.

PT J
AN ZOOR15208050952
DT Article
TI New species of the genus Rhopalotettix Hancock, 1910 (Orthoptera:
   Tetrigidae, Metrodorinae) from Vietnam.
AU Storozhenko, S. Yu. (storozhenko@ibss.dvo.ru) 
SO Zoosystematica Rossica
VL 24
IS 1
PS 90-93
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Rhopalotettix vietnamensis sp. nov. is described from Vietnam. The new
   species is similar to R. chinensis Tinkham, 1939 in a distinct median
   carina of the fastigium (in all the other congeners, median carina is
   absent) and differs from the latter species by the rostrum with almost
   parallel lateral sides and by a narrow tegmen, visible part of which is
   2.3 times narrower than mid femur (in R. chinensis, rostrum with the
   lateral sides gradually converging to the acute apex, and visible part
   of tegmen is almost as broad as mid femur).
C1 Storozhenko, S. Yu.; Russian Acad Sci, Inst Biol & Soil Sci,
   Vladivostok, 690022, Russia, Russia.
EM storozhenko@ibss.dvo.ru
OI Sergey.Yu., Storozhenko/0000-0001-9269-4043
SC Zoology
SN 0320-9180
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Oriental region;
   Eurasia; Asia
DE Rhopalotettix vietnamensis [Vietnam /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Orthoptera, Saltatoria
OR Rhopalotettix vietnamensis (Saltatoria): [Sp nov, Vietnam, P. 91]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15208050952
DA 2020-09-17
ER

DT Article
TI New species of the subgenus Elgodexoris (genus Dexoris) and a new genus
   of the tribe Dexorini (Leptolycinae) from East Africa, with notes on the
   status of Mimolibnetinae (Coleoptera: Lycidae).
AU Kazantsev, S.V. (kazantss@mail.ru) 
SO Zoosystematica Rossica
VL 24
IS 1
PS 99-107
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new genus Kurbatovia gen. nov. is erected for Dexoris chome Boca,
   Grebennikov et Masek, 2013. Four new species, Dexoris (Elgodexoris)
   rwandensis sp. nov., D. (E.) nyungwensis sp. nov., D. (E.) svetlanae sp.
   nov. and D. (E.) maikoensis sp. nov., are described from Rwanda and the
   Democratic Republic of the Congo. A key to species of the subgenus
   Elgodexoris Boca et Bocaova, 1988 is provided. Mimolibnetinae is
   revalidated as a distinct subfamily.

TI A new species of Phradis Forster (Hymenoptera: Ichneumonidae:
   Tersilochinae) from Japan.
AU Khalaim, A.I. (ptera@mail.ru) 
SO Zoosystematica Rossica
VL 24
IS 1
PS 108-112
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species, Phradis hikosanus sp. nov. from South Japan is described
   and illustrated. It differs from other species of the genus in its
   disproportionately small globose head and strongly compressed laterally
   mesosoma (lateral sides of mesosoma are almost flat). A key to three
   species of Phradis occurring in Japan is provided.

PT J
AN ZOOR15207040455
DT Article
TI Siphonostomatoid copepods infecting Squalus acutipinnis Regan, 1908 off
   South Africa.
AU Dippenaar, S.M. (susan.dippenaar@ul.ac.za) 
   Molele, R.A.
SO African Journal of Marine Science
VL 37
IS 4
PS 605-608
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Squalus acutipinnis (previously included in S. megalops) individuals
   caught off the east, south and west coasts of South Africa were examined
   for siphonostomatoid copepod infection. Collected siphonostomatoids were
   fixed and preserved in 70% ethanol and studied under microscopes using
   both transmitted and incidental light. The copepods were identified and
   the host-parasite associations estimated by calculating their
   prevalence, mean intensity and mean abundance. The siphonostomatoids
   represented four families and six species, and included new host records
   for Nemesis sp., Lernaeopoda sp. and Eudactylina acanthii, and a new
   geographical record for E. acanthii. Squalus acutipinnis individuals
   were infected by relatively low loads of siphonostomatoids. The most
   commonly found species was Achtheinus pinguis, the only species found
   off all three coasts. There was no difference in the prevalence of A.
   pinguis in sharks sampled off the three coasts but the highest mean
   intensity was found on the East Coast followed by the West Coast. The
   overall prevalence of A. pinguis was 33.6%, and was an order of
   magnitude higher than that of the other siphonostomatoids recorded. At
   such low levels of infection it will thus be necessary to examine a
   large number of hosts to determine the biodiversity of siphonostomatoids
   and geographical differences in prevalence in South African waters.
C1 Dippenaar, S.M.; Univ Limpopo, Dept Biodivers, Sovenga, South Africa,
   South Africa.
EM susan.dippenaar@ul.ac.za
RI Dippenaar, Susan/O-1700-2015
OI Dippenaar, Susan/0000-0002-1780-5548

DT Article
TI Notes on the family Gelastocoridae (Hemiptera: Heteroptera) in Southern
   Chile with descriptions of a new subgenus and a new species.
FT Notas sobre la familia Gelastocoridae (Hemiptera: Heteroptera) en el
   extremo sur de Chile, con descripcion de un subgenero y especie nuevos.
AU Faundez, Eduardo I. (ed.faundez@gmail.com) 
   Ashworth, Allan C.
SO Anales del Instituto de la Patagonia
VL 43
IS 2
PS 69-74
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB A fossil gelastocorid, Nerthra subantarctica Faundez & Ashworth sp. nov,
   is described from Puerto Eden ([approximately]49 [degree]S), Ultima
   Esperanza province, Magallanes Region, Chile. The new species is
   described on basis of a head and a pronotum. Although it is a fossil
   species it is not believed to be extinct. New records and first
   description of the male are given for Nerthra praecipua Todd, 1957, and
   a new subgenus Rhinodermacoris Faundez subgen. nov., is erected to place
   N. praecipua. The male of N. praecipua is described for the first time.
   The new records for N. praecipua extends its north distribution up to
   Los Rios Region ([approximately]40 [degree]S). On the other hand N.
   subantarctica is the southernmost distributed gelastocorid in South
   America.

DT Article
TI Detection of Leishmania sp in Rattus rattus in the city of Corrientes,
   Argentina.
FT Deteccion de Leishmania sp. en Rattus rattus de la ciudad de Corrientes,
   Argentina.
AU Ruiz, R.M. (raquel_moni-caruiz@hotmail.com) 
   Bastiani, C.E.
   De Biasio, M.B.
   Alegre, E.A.
   Ramirez, N.N.
SO Archivos de Medicina Veterinaria (Valdivia)
VL 47
IS 3
PS 401-407
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB Leishmaniasis is an important public health problem in tropical and
   subtropical countries worldwide. The identification of natural hosts of
   Leishmania is fundamental to better understand the epidemiology of the
   disease. The importance of rodents as reservoir hosts for different
   Leishmania species have already been described in different countries,
   however there are not reports of this situation in Argentina. The aim of
   this work was to capture rodents in the city of Corrientes, Argentina
   and detect Leishmania spp. in spleens of rodents through molecular
   analysis using nested PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction) technical and by
   light microscopy to detect amastigotes. The results showed that sixty
   four rodents were collected, sixty three of them were identified as
   Rattus rattus and only one as Mus musculus. Positive results were
   obtained by Nested PCR, Leishmania DNA was detected in 43.7% of 64
   tissue samples (first round of nested PCR), 46.8% (second round of
   nested PCR) and 3.1% by light microscopy. This is the first report of
   its kind where synanthropic rodents were found to be naturally infected
   by Leishmania spp. in Corrientes city, Argentina. Further studies are
   needed to evaluate other organs and to differentiate Leishmania species.
C1 Ruiz, R.M.; Sargento Cabral 2139, Corrientes, RA-3400, Argentina,
   Argentina.
EM raquel_moni-caruiz@hotmail.com
SC Zoology; Parasitology
SN 0301-732X
BD Parasites diseases and disorders; Parasites; Hosts; Land zones;
   Neotropical region; South America
DE Leishmania [Mammalian hosts / Mus musculus / New record] [ / Rattus
   rattus / ] [Argentina / Corrientes / ]. 
   Mus musculus; Rattus rattus [Protozoan parasites / Leishmania / New
   record] [Argentina / Corrientes / ]. 
TN Chordates; Mammals; Protozoans; Rodents; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia, Rodentia, Muridae, Protozoa,
   Sarcomastigophora, Mastigophora, Zoomastigophorea, Kinetoplastida
OR Mus musculus (Muridae): [Host; New record]. 
   Rattus rattus (Muridae): [Host; New record]. 
   Leishmania (Kinetoplastida): [Parasite; New record]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15207041517
DA 2020-09-17

DT Article
TI A NEW SPECIES OF THE AMMONITE GENUS NEOCHETOCERAS SPATH (OPPELIIDAE)
   FROM THE HYBONOTUM ZONE (LOWER TITHONIAN) OF SOUTHERN GERMANY, WITH
   COMMENTS ON THE PHYLOGENY OF THE GENUS.
AU Scherzinger, Armin (Armin.Scherzinger@t-online.de) 
   Parent, Horacio
   Schweigert, Guenter
SO Boletin del Instituto de Fisiografia y Geologia Universidad Nacional de
   Rosario
VL 85
PS 1-12
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB We here introduce a new species of the Submediterranean oppeliid genus
   Neochetoceras, N. mohri n.sp., represented by both macro- and
   microconchs. N. mohri n. sp. is better recorded than any other nominal
   species of this genus and links the early representatives of the lineage
   with the type species, N. steraspis (Oppel). Possible phyletic ancestors
   and the biogeographic distribution are briefly discussed. The
   Neochetoceras succession in the uppermost Kimmeridgian (Beckeri Zone) to
   Lower Tithonian (Hybonotum and Mucronatum zones) is summarized.

PT J
AN ZOOR15207040506
DT Article
TI CALLOVIAN NAUTILOIDS FROM THE NEUQUEN BASIN, ARGENTINA.
AU Parent, Horacio (parent@fceia.unr.edu.ar) 
   Garrido, Alberto C.
SO Boletin del Instituto de Fisiografia y Geologia Universidad Nacional de
   Rosario
VL 85
PS 13-18
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB For the first time Callovian nautiloids from the Neuquen Basin
   (Argentina) are described. All the material was collected with precise
   stratigraphic control based on the local ammonite successions. Most
   specimens belong to Cenoceras sp. A from the Lotena Fm at Picun Leufu
   (Patagoniensis Z., lower Upper Callovian) and Los Molles Fm at Chacay
   Melehu (Proximum Z., upper Lower Callovian). Additionally, one specimen
   assigned to Cenoceras sp. B comes from the Lotena Fm at Picun Leufu
   (Patagoniensis Z.). Jurassic nautiloids are usually scarce all around
   the world with respect to ammonites, but in the Neuquen Basin they are
   very scarce. Our collections of cephalopods have produced some fifteen
   nautiloids besides more than 5.000 ammonites collected in Late Callovian
   to Late Tithonian sequences of the Neuquen Basin. This asymmetric
   pattern of abundance is surely based, at least in part, on the different
   reproductive strategies of ammonoids and nautiloids.
C1 Parent, Horacio; Univ Nacl Rosario, Lab Paleontol, Pellegrini 250,
   Rosario, Santa Fe, RA-2000, Argentina, Argentina.
EM parent@fceia.unr.edu.ar
SC Zoology
SN 1666-115X
BD Systematics; Land zones; Neotropical region; South America; Geological
   time periods; Mesozoic

   systematics] [Jurassic / Callovian / ]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Cephalopoda, Nautiloidea
OR Nautiloidea (Cephalopoda): [Fossil; New record]. 
   Cenoceras - Hyatt 1883 (Nautiloidea): [Fossil; New record].

PT J
AN ZOOR15207042173
DT Article
TI Ecology, ontogenesis and description of the Catalan edaphic millipede
   Eopsychrosoma serrapradense n. g., n. sp (Diplopoda, Chordeumatida,
   Craspedosomatidea, Vandeleumatidae).
FT Ecologie, ontogenese et description d'un Diplopode edaphique de
   Catalogne: Eopsychrosoma serrapradense n. g., n. sp. (Diplopoda,
   Chordeumatida, Craspedosomatidea, Vandeleumatidae).
AU Serra, Antoni (aserra@ub.edu) 
   Mauries, Jean-Paul
SO Bulletin de la Societe d'Histoire Naturelle de Toulouse
VL 151
PS 15-28
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB Within the context of a study on the edaphic arthropods inhabiting an
   oak grove of the Serra de Prades (Tarragona, Catalonia, Spain) samplings
   were made during one year, every month (May 2002-May 2003), using two
   different methods. First, five samples of soil with edaphic soundings
   separating three horizons were taken, and then the arthropod extraction
   was made with Berlese-Tullgren funnels. The second method involved the
   installation of 21 pitfalls allowing to capture arthropods of the
   surface (NO), and at 2 (N2) and 4 cm (N4) depth. Amongst the arthropods
   captured there are 213 specimens of a new species of an edaphic little
   millipede belonging to a new genus, Eopsychrosoma serrapradense n. g.,
   n. sp. These new taxa are described and included in the family
   Vandeleumatidae within the classification of the craspedosomatid
   millipedes. The diagnosis of this family is revised as well as its
   generic contents (five genera) redefined with a key for identification.
   The high number of available samples allowed a reconstitution of the
   ontogenesis of the new species and an outline of the life cycle, which
   probably involves only one year. The structure of the population and the
   presence of adults suggest the existence of two periods of sexual
   activity, one in January-February, and the other in May-June. The number
   of samples gathered with pitfalls is poor and indicates a weak mobility.
   The use of edaphic soundings is therefore a more suitable method for
   population evaluations. Regarding the temporal distribution, no
   significant differences were noticed in the densities throughout the
   whole sampling period, whatever the horizon. Values for activity density
   indicate the existence of two periods, in spring and in autumn, when the
   number of captures is higher. The population is mainly located in the
   organic horizons (L/F and H) and has a clear aggregative repartition.
   The abiotic factors, such as temperature and precipitations, influence
   the species repartition only in the more superficial horizons.
C1 Serra, Antoni; Univ Barcelona, Fac Biol, Av Diagonal 645, Barcelona,
   E-08028, Spain, Spain.
EM aserra@ub.edu
SC Zoology
SN 0758-4113
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe
DE Eopsychrosoma serrapradense [Spain /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Invertebrates; Myriapods
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Myriapoda, Diplopoda
OR Eopsychrosoma (Diplopoda): [Gen nov, Of family Vandeleumatidae, Type
   species Eopsychrosoma serrapradense, p. 17]. 
   Eopsychrosoma serrapradense (Diplopoda): [Sp nov, Spain, P. 18]. 
   Vandeleumatidae (Diplopoda): [Key to genera, P. 17]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15207042173
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR15207042174
DT Article
TI Botolana, a new genus of groundwater cirolanid isopod (Crustacea) from
   Morocco.
AU Coineau, Nicole (n.coineau@orange.fr) 
   Boutin, Claude
SO Bulletin de la Societe d'Histoire Naturelle de Toulouse
VL 151
PS 29-34
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new genus of crustacean isopod from ground waters, Botolana gen. nov.
   (Cirolanidae) is erected to accommodate the species Typhlocirolana
   leptura Botosaneanu, Boutin & Henry, 1985 whose generic assignation
   appeared to be questionable. The genus Botolana differs from
   Typhlocirolana in its more slender and more rounded body, and its long
   posterior pereiopods and uropods. Botolana nov. gen. is also
   distinguished from Typhlocirolana by the antennules shorter than the
   antennal peduncle, the coxae without acute posterior angle, a
   rudimentary suture of the exopod of pleopod 2 in the male, and the
   pleotelson shape with greatest width located sub-proximally instead of
   basally. Moreover, the uropod sympod is clearly shorter than rami. These
   differences delineate the two genera, while still demonstrating a close
   relationship. The distribution range of Botolana leptura is limited to a
   small area from Marrakesh and close surroundings to Chichaoua in the
   Haouz plain, and to the northern piedmont of the Jbilet mountain range
   (Morocco). In contrast, Typhlocirolana is widely distributed in Morocco,
   Algeria, Tunisia and in the western Mediterranean. Such a wide
   distribution of Typhlocirolana suggests that species of this genus could
   have less strict ecological requirements than Botolana leptura which
   might inhabit finer sediments whereas Typhlocirolana species might
   prefer coarse grained substrates.
C1 Coineau, Nicole; 67 Ave Puig del Mas, Banyuls Sur Mer, F-66650, France,
   France.
EM n.coineau@orange.fr
SC Zoology
SN 0758-4113
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Combination
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Malacostraca, Eumalacostraca,
   Peracarida, Isopoda
OR Botolana (Isopoda): [Gen nov, Of family Cirolanidae, Type species
   Typhlocirolana leptura Botosaneanu, Boutin & Henry 1985, p. 30]. 
   Botolana leptura - (Botosaneanu, Boutin & Henry 1985) (Isopoda): [Comb
   nov, Transferred from Typhlocirolana, p. 30]. 
   Typhlocirolana leptura - Botosaneanu, Boutin & Henry 1985 (Isopoda):
   [Designated type species for new genus, Botolana, p. 30].

DT Article
TI Microcharon tellensis, a new Microparasellidae (Crustacea, Isopoda,
   Janiroidea) from the ground waters of Algeria.
AU Boutin, Claude
   Boulancome, Mohamed
   Merzoug, Djemoi
   Coineau, Nicole (n.coineau@orange.fi) 
SO Bulletin de la Societe d'Histoire Naturelle de Toulouse
VL 151
PS 35-45
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Up to now, the isopod genus Microcharon (Crustacea, Microparasellidae)
   was known from Algeria by two species. A new species from the northern
   border of the Blidean Atlas is described. Microcharon tellensis sp. nov.
   is characterized by a unique character combination including the sexual
   dimorphism of the antennules; the plumose seta of the second antennulary
   article hardly surpassing the appendage apex; the male second pleopod
   with an appendix masculina S-shaped, long and thin, and a sympod without
   distal lobe; the female second pleopod long and medially slightly
   concave. The new species shows affinities with Microcharon zibani from
   the southern piedmont of the Saharan Atlas. Inland species of
   Microcharon are derived from marine ancestors. The Two-Step Model of
   Colonization and Evolution provides an understanding of the origin of
   fresh groundwater stygobionts that are marine relicts. The ancestors of
   both Microcharon zibani and M.tellensis could have settled in inland
   ground waters during the regression of the large marine gulfs of the
   Burdigalian. M. karamani is a member of the Ibero-Maghrebin niessoulii
   lineage. Like other representatives of this phylogenetic group, it might
   have colonized the southern Blidean Atlas ground waters during the
   Turonian or the Senonian marine regressions. Further prospective
   sampling in Algeria will reveal the true diversity of Microcharon in
   this country.
C1 Coineau, Nicole; 67 Ave Puig del Mas, Banyuls Sur Mer, F-66650, France,
   France.
EM n.coineau@orange.fi
SC Zoology
SN 0758-4113
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Zoogeography; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Africa

    / ].

DT Article
TI Revision of Philoscaptus Brethes, 1919 and description of a new genus
   (Coleoptera, Melolonthidae, Dynastinae).
AU Moron Rios, Miguel Angel (moronrios.miguelangel@gmail.com) 
   Grossi, Paschoal Coelho
SO Entomotropica
VL 30
PS 1-11
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus Philoscaptus Brethes, 1919, is revised and found to be
   monotypic, including P. bonariensis (Burmeister) a species found mainly
   in open areas along the Parana River basin, in Brazil, Uruguay,
   Argentina and Paraguay (new country record). The new genus
   Saccharoscaptus is described for P. laminifer Dechambre, differentiated
   by mandibles with one weak rounded apical tooth, apex of clypeus with no
   denticles, frons excavate, male with blade like process on clypeus and
   small pronotal tubercles. A key for males of the Neotropical
   Pentodontini genera is given and the current status of Ligyrus
   Burmeister and Tomarus Erichson is discussed and a checklist with the
   known species included in each genus is also provided.

   Mexico.

DT Article
TI Lance fly (Diptera: Lonchaeidae) host plants in the State of Sao Paulo,
   Southeast Brazil.
FT Plantas hospederas de moscas de la fruta (Diptera: Lonchaeidae) en el
   Estado de Sao Paulo, Brasil.
AU Raga, Adalton (adalton@biologico.sp.gov.br) 
   de Souza-Filho, Miguel Francisco
   Strikis, Pedro Carlos
   Nalesso Marangoni Montes, Sonia Maria
SO Entomotropica
VL 30
PS 57-68
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Many species of Lonchaeidae predominate in the complex of fruit flies
   (Tephritoidea) infesting more species of host fruits that the species of
   Tephritidae. In the southern hemisphere, very little is known about the
   diversity of the species of Lonchaeidae and their host relationship.
   This paper records the species of Lonchaeidae and their respective host
   plants as recovered out of a total of 1,522 samples of fruit relating to
   113 plant species coming from 94 municipalities of the State of Sao
   Paulo, Brazil. A total of 26,906 Lonchaeidae adults were obtained,
   belonging to 14 species of Neosilba McAlpine, Dasiops inedulis Steyskal,
   Dasiops frieseni Norrbom & McAlpine and Lonchaea sp. Specimens of
   Neosilba represented 99.78 % of the adults recovered: N. bella Strikis &
   Prado, N. bifida Strikis & Prado, N. certa (Walker), N. cornuphallus
   Strikis, N. dimidiata Curran, N. inesperata Strikis & Prado, N.
   glaberrima (Wiedemann), N. laura Strikis, N. paramerolatus Strikis, N.
   parva Hennig, N. pradoi Strikis & Lerena, N. pendula (Bezzi), N. perezi
   (Romero & Ruppel) and N. zadolicha McAlpine & Steyskal. Neosilba
   zadolicha is predominant, abundant and generalist species.
C1 Raga, Adalton; Inst Biol, Lab Econ Entomol, POB 70, Campinas, SP,
   Brazil, Brazil.
EM adalton@biologico.sp.gov.br

   zones; Neotropical region; South America

   /  / ] [Abiotic factors / Season / ] [Brazil / Sao Paulo / ]. 
   Neosilba perezi [Food plants / Malpighia emarginata / New record]
   [Brazil / Sao Paulo / ].

   Lonchaeidae

TI TAXONOMY OF THE KATYDIDS (ORTHOPTERA: TETTIGONIIDAE) FROM EAST ASIA AND
   ADJACENT ISLANDS. COMMUNICATION 10.
AU Gorochov, A.V. (orthopt@zin.ru) 
SO Far Eastern Entomologist

U1 0

AB Two new genera (Epiproctopsis gen. n. and Borneopsis gen. n.) and 16 new
   species and subspecies from the genera Xiphidiopsis Redt., Alloteratura
   Heb. and Kuzicus Gor. are described from Malaysia and Indonesia:
   Epiproctopsis silvamontana sp. n.; Borneopsis divulsa sp. n.; B.
   contigua sp. n.; Xiphidiopsis tembelingi sp. n.; X. beybienkoi mada
   subsp. n.; X. b. thaica subsp. n.; X.? jugata sp. n.; Alloteratura
   breviuscula sp. n.; A. sarawaki sp. n.; A. eubispina sp. n.; A.
   megaspina sp. n.; A. longicercata sulawesi subsp. n.; A. parvispina sp.
   n.; A. triloba allopatrica subsp. n., A. vietnami sp. n.; Kuzicus? mirus
   sp. n. One former genus is reduced up to a subgenus (Meconemopsis Karny,
   stat. n.) of the genus Alloteratura. A previously unknown male of A.
   curta Gor. is also described. New data on geographic distribution,
   morphological characters and generic belonging of some other species are
   given.

DT Article
TI A New Species of Parachauliodes (Megaloptera: Corydalidae) from Fukui
   Prefecture, Central Honshu, Japan.
AU Shimonoya, Toyokazu
SO Fukui-shi Shizenshi Hakubutsukan Kenkyu Hokoku
VL 62
PS 43-52
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA Japanese
U1 0
U2 0
AB In the present article one new species of the genus Parachauliodes
   Weele, 1909, named Parachauliodes inopinatus sp. nov., is described from
   Fukui Prefecture, Central Honshu, Japan. It is distinguished by the
   forewing venation (posterior branch of 2A) of adult and by the
   respiratory tubes of larva from Parachauliodes continentalis and
   Parachauliodes japonicus. It resembles Parachauliodes asahinai,
   described from South Korea by Liu, Hayashi and Yang, 2008. It differs
   from P. asahinai in the shape of male genitalia.

DT Article
TI A Hirnantian deep-water refuge for warm-water ostracods in Baltoscandia.
AU Truuver, Karin (karin.truuver@ut.ee) 
   Meidla, Tonu
SO Geological Quarterly
VL 59
IS 4
PS 738-749
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB The latest Ordovician is marked by a severe climate change, the
   Hirnantian glaciation. This climatic event affected many marine taxa
   including ostracods. Rich and abundant ostracod assemblages of the
   Baltic Palaeobasin were severely impoverished. Many of the typical
   pre-Hirnatian warm-water ostracod species died out, but also some
   distinct, cold-water species appeared. Two very different but likely
   coeval latest Ordovician ostracod assemblages are recorded in the Baltic
   countries and northeastern Poland. The latest Ordovician Estonian Shelf
   (inner ramp) is characterized by the Medianella aequa association whilst
   sections in the Livonian Basin (middle to outer ramp) reveal the
   Harpabollia harparum association that is thought to represent a
   cold-water assemblage belonging to the Dalmanitina-Hirnantia Fauna sensu
   lato. A transitional assemblage composed of a "species mixture" of
   typical Hirnantian cold-water and some pre-Hirnantian warm-water
   ostracod species is described for the first time from the Ketrzyn IG 1
   borehole, northeastern Poland. The assemblage is dominated by
   Cryptophyllus plus sp. n. The genus Cryptophyllus is rare in the two
   other well-known assemblages. The discovery suggests that marginal parts
   of the Baltic Palaeobasin could serve as a kind of refuge for the last
   representatives of the ostracod faunas of the inner shelf of Baltic
   Palaeobasin. The Hirnantian assemblage is replaced by the low-diversity
   recovery assemblage that is dated as late Hirnantian-Silurian in Estonia
   and other areas. This suggests that the position of the systemic
   boundary in the Ketrzyn borehole and elsewhere in northeastern Poland
   should be re-evaluated.
C1 Truuver, Karin; Univ Tartu, Inst Ecol & Earth Sci, Ravila 14A, Tartu,
   Estonia, Estonia.
EM karin.truuver@ut.ee
SC Zoology; Paleontology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Geochemistry
   &Geophysics
SN 1641-7291
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Ecology; Abiotic factors; Physical
   factors; Zoogeography; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe;
   Geological time periods; Palaeozoic
DE Cryptophyllus pius [Poland /  / new species] [Ordovician /  / ]. 
   Ostracoda [Fossil assemblages /  / systematics] [Geophysical events /
   Glaciation / ] [Zoogeography / Deep-water refuge / ] [Poland / Northeast
   / ] [Ordovician / Hirnantian / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Ostracoda
OR Ostracoda (Crustacea): [Fossil]. 
   Cryptophyllus pius (Ostracoda): [Sp nov, Poland, Ordovician, P. 740;
   Fossil]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15207041332
OA Bronze
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR15207041335
DT Article
TI The Belemnitella stratigraphy of the Upper Campanian-basal Maastrichtian
   of the Middle Vistula section, central Poland.
AU Remin, Zbigniew (zbyh@uw.edu.pl) 
SO Geological Quarterly
VL 59
IS 4
PS 783-813
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB This taxonomy and stratigraphy of the Upper Campanian and Lower
   Maastrichtian Belemnitella lineages, from the Middle Vistula section,
   based on new collections, is presented. The correlation to the basal
   Maastrichtian standard GSSP at Tercis, France, is provided based on
   inoceramid bivalve stratigraphy. The artificial neural networks (ANN),
   particularly the self-organizing Kohonen algorithm, was applied to
   taxonomic discrimination. Eight morphotypes within the genus
   Belemnitella, understood here as natural species populations, were
   recognized. Five of these are assigned to known taxa: Belemnitella
   mucronata, B. posterior, B. minor(= B. minor I and B. minor II), B.
   langei and B. najdini; and three, B. sp. a, B. sp. 1 and B. sp. 2, are
   left in open nomenclature. Four Belemnitella zones are proposed. Due to
   its palaeogeographic position, between Western and Eastern Europe, the
   Middle Vistula section is characterized by the co-occurrence of
   Belemnitella species from those two areas. Consequently, it enables
   better correlation of Belemnitella-based schemes; the East European B.
   najdini and B. posterior are placed next to West European B. minor
   chronospecies I and II. The Campanian/Maastrichtian boundary, as
   currently defined, is placed at the top of the najdini posterior Zone,
   which is an equivalent of the Belemnella-based boundary, i.e. at the
   base of the Belemnella obtuse / Belemnella vistulensis zones. Within the
   top of the najdini posterior Zone occurs a level (an interval of only a
   few metres), where nearly all of the Upper Campanian Belemnitella
   disappear. This level coincides with taxonomic changes observed within
   the co-occurring representatives of genus Belemnella.
C1 Remin, Zbigniew; Univ Warsaw, Fac Geol, Zwirki & Wigury 93, Warsaw,
   PL-02089, Poland, Poland.
EM zbyh@uw.edu.pl
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology
SN 1641-7291
BD Systematics; Ecology; Distribution within habitat; Zoogeography; Land
   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods;
   Mesozoic
DE Belemnitella [Zonation /  / systematics] [Zoogeography /
   Palaeobiogeography / ] [Poland / Central / stratigraphical distribution]
   [Cretaceous / Upper Campanian-Lower Maastrichtian / ].

DT Article
TI A new Nebria species (Carabidae: Nebriini) and a new Deltomerus species
   (Carabidae: Patrobini) from high mountain areas of Azarbayjan-e Gharbi
   Province, Iran.
AU Muilwijk, J. (Jan.Muilwijk@gmail.com) 
SO Iranian Journal of Animal Biosystematics
VL 11
IS 1
PS 57-63
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB During a comprehensive study of the genus Stenus (Staphylinidae) along
   streams and river banks in Iran, some ground beetles (Carabidae) were
   also collected. In the high mountain areas along the Iranian-Turkish
   border in the province of Azarbayjan -e Gharbi, a Nebria and a
   Deltomerus species were found. These Nebria and Deltomerus species were
   clearly different from known Iranian species, but related to Turkish
   species. Nebria (Nebria) azarbayanei sp. nov. is compared with the
   related N. (N.) thonitida Ledoux and Roux 1990. Deltomerus (Deltomerus)
   veldkampi sp. nov. is compared with the closely related D. (D.) lodozi
   Ledoux 1976. Differences between these new species and the related
   species are discussed. Pterostichus cryobioides Chaudoir 1868 and Nebria
   (N.) mandibularis Bates 1872 are recorded for the first time from Iran.
