DT Article
TI A review of the Oligocene Limopsidae of the North Sea Basin (Mollusca:
   Bivalvia).
AU Janssen, Ronald (ronald.janssen@senckenberg.de) 
SO Geologica Saxonica
VL 61
IS 1
PS 7-33
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB In the course of a review of the Limopsidae Dall 1895 from the Oligocene
   of the North Sea Basin 13 species and their generic assignment are
   discussed. The following five species are described as new: Cosmetopsis
   latdorfensis from the Late Eocene/Earliest Oligocene Latdorfian stage,
   Paracratis magdeburgensis and P. muelleri from the Early Oligocene
   Rupelian sands of Mammendorf, Cosmetopsis mothsorum from the Early
   Rupelian Rupel Clay Formation of Malliss and Cosmetopsis glimmerodensis
   from the Early Chattian. Neotypes are established for Limopsis retifera
   Semper 1861 and L. iniquidens Sandberger 1861 and priority of L.
   retifera is demonstrated. The genus Nucunella Orbigny 1850 is excluded
   from the Limopsidae and transferred to Glycymerididae Dall 1908. The
   nomenclature of some taxa is corrected: Limopsis albrechtvalki Marquet,
   Lenaerts & Laporte 2012 is a synonym of Limopsis subscalaris Orbigny
   1852, and for the North Sea Basin Miocene species hitherto known as
   "Limopsis anomala Eichwald" the taxon Aspalima decussata (Nyst &
   Westendorp 1839) is suggested.

   Senckenberganlage 25, 60325 Frankfurt am Main, Germany, Germany.

   Palaeogene

DT Article
TI Lutetiella, a new genus of hydrobioids from the Middle Eocene (Lutetian)
   of the Upper Rhine Graben and Paris Basin (Mollusca: Gastropoda:
   Rissooidea s. lat.).
AU Kadolsky, Dietrich (kadolsky@btsgeo.com) 
SO Geologica Saxonica
VL 61
IS 1
PS 35-51
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Lutetiella n.gen. is proposed for Lutetiella hartkopfi n. sp. (type
   species) and L. conica (Prevost 1821) from the Middle Eocene (Lutetian)
   of the Upper Rhine Graben and Paris Basin, respectively. The protoconch
   microsculpture of L. hartkopfi n. sp. was occasionally preserved and
   proved to be a variant of the plesiomorphic hydrobioid pattern. The new
   genus is tentatively placed in Hydrobiidae. Problems in the
   classification of hydrobioid fossils are discussed, arising from the
   dearth of distinguishing shell characters. Previous attributions of L.
   conica to Assiminea or Peringia are shown to be incorrect. The name
   Paludina conica Ferussac 1814, a senior primary homonym of Paludina
   conica Prevost 1821, and denoting an unidentifiable hydrobioid,
   threatens the validity of the name Lutetiella conica (Prevost 1821) and
   should be suppressed. Both Lutetiella species are interpreted to undergo
   a planktic veliger larval stadium and lived in shallow brackish waters.
   The species difference may be due to geographical isolation between the
   Paris Basin and the Upper Rhine Graben.
C1 Kadolsky, Dietrich; 66 Heathhurst Road, Sanderstead, Surrey CR2 0BA,
   United Kingdom, United Kingdom.
EM kadolsky@btsgeo.com
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Entomology; Developmental Biology;
   Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 1617-8467

   position; General morphology; Life cycle and development; Development;
   Ecology; Zoogeography; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe;
   Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary; Palaeogene
DE Lutetiella [General morphology /  / systematics] [Larval development / 
   / ] [Ecology / Palaeoecology / ] [Zoogeography / Palaeobiogeography / ]
   [France / Paris Basin / distribution] [Germany / Rhine Graben / ]
   [Eocene /  / New genus] [ / Lutetian / ]. 
   Lutetiella hartkopfi [Germany /  / new species] [Eocene /  / ]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Gastropoda, Prosobranchia, Mesogastropoda,
   Rissoidea, Viviparoidea
OR Lutetiella (Rissoidea): [Gen nov, Of family Hydrobiidae?, Type species
   Lutetiella hartkopfi, p. 36, Eocene; Fossil]. 
   Lutetiella conica - (Prevost 1821) (Rissoidea): [Comb nov, Transferred
   from Peringia, p. 41]. 
   Lutetiella hartkopfi (Rissoidea): [Sp nov, Germany, Eocene, P. 38;
   Fossil]. 
   Peringia conica - (Prevost 1821) (Rissoidea): [Referred to, New genus
   Lutetiella, p. 41]. 
   Paludina conica - Ferussac 1814 (Viviparoidea): [Status, P. 43].

PT J
AN ZOOR15203015425
DT Article
TI Non-marine and marginally marine mollusk faunas in the European
   Tertiary, 11. - A mollusk fauna from the Untere Bunte Molasse of the
   Alpine foreland (Bavaria, Oligocene): The locality Habach 5.
FT Nichtmarine und perihaline Molluskenfaunen im Tertiaer Europas, 11. -
   Eine Molluskenfauna aus der Unteren Bunten Molasse des Alpenvorlandes
   (Bayern, Oligozaen): Die Fundstelle Habach 5.
AU Kadolsky, Dietrich (kadolsky@btsgeo.com) 
SO Geologica Saxonica
VL 61
IS 1
PS 53-72
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB The mollusks associated with the vertebrates collected and described by
   Gohlich & Fahlbusch (2000) from the locality Habach 5 are described. The
   finds are from the lower part of the Untere Bunte Molasse, which is part
   of the subalpine Lower Freshwater Molasse in Bavaria. The mammals
   indicated the attribution of Habach 5 to Mammal Zone MP25 in the Late
   Rupelian. The mollusks comprise a freshwater association (Lymnaeidae,
   Planorbidae) and a terrestrial association (Diplommatinidae:
   Cochlostomatinae, Pomatiidae, Vertiginidae, Valloniidae, Limacidae und
   Helicoidea indet.). Atopippeutis muelleri n. gen. n. sp. is a new taxon;
   Pomatias (Neobembridgia) antiquus schneidi (Jooss 1912) is
   differentiated from related Neobembridgia taxa. Faunal relationships
   exist mainly with the Calcaire d'Etampes in the Paris Basin, and with
   the Pomatias-Susswasserkalk of the Ries region, which both are also of
   Late Rupelian age. Faunal similarities with the younger
   Hochheim-Formation of the Mainz Basin indicate a bias caused by the high
   diversity and good knowledge of the latter fauna. The mollusk
   associations of Habach 5 are interpreted as having lived in shallow and
   stagnant or slowly flowing water bodies, respectively in shrub and tree
   covered lowlands such as a river plain.
C1 Kadolsky, Dietrich; 66 Heathhurst Road, Sanderstead, Surrey CR2 0BA,
   United Kingdom, United Kingdom.
EM kadolsky@btsgeo.com

PT J
AN ZOOR15203015426
DT Article
TI Fossil remains of selachiens and chimaera from the Muschelschluff and
   Phosphoritknollenhorizont of Zwenkau near Leipzig.
FT Fossile Reste von Selachiern und Chimaeren aus dem Muschelschluff und
   Phosphoritknollenhorizont von Zwenkau bei Leipzig.
AU Leder, Ronny M. (leder.ronnymaik@googlemail.com) 
SO Geologica Saxonica
VL 61
IS 1
PS 73-90
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB Fossil remains of selachiens and chimaera from the Muschelschluff and
   Phosphoritknollenhorizont (Bohlen-Formation) of Zwenkau near Leipzig
   were described. The findings comprise new taxa or taxa that for the
   appropriate strata very rare are. Beside the new described genus
   Arnomobula gen. nov., the mobuloid rays Arnomobula eythrai gen. et spec.
   nov. and Argoubia arnoldmu�lleri spec. nov. as well as the scyliorhinid
   shark Scyliorhinus kannenbergi spec. nov. were described and verified as
   new species. As type horizons the Phosphoritknollenhorizont and
   Muschelschluff were determined. Beside the first description of oral
   teeth of the saw shark Pristiophorus rupeliensis Steuerbaut & Herman
   1987 for the fossil site further pretty rare rostral teeth of the
   species as well as a fragment of the palatinal tooth plate of Chimaera
   gosseleti Winkler 1880 could be described. The fossil samples mirror the
   faunal progress in a marginal sea at the maximum transgression of the
   North Sea.

TI Rare birds in Morocco: 20th (2014) report of the Moroccan Rare Birds
   Committee.
FT Les oiseaux rares au Maroc Rapport de la Commission d'Homologation
   Marocaine Numero 20 (2014).
AU Bergier, Patrick (pbergier@yahoo.fr) 
   Franchimont, Jacques
SO Go-South Bulletin
VL 12
PS 1-23
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB In 2014, MRBC examined 109 new records of which 92 were accepted. These
   included the first Moroccan records of Long-tailed Duck Clangula
   hyemalis, Upland Sandpiper Bartramia longicauda, Senegal Parrot
   Poicephalus senegalus, White-throated Beeeater Merops albicollis and
   Spotted Flycatcher "balearica" Muscicapa striata balearica, the second
   of ( Magnificent?) Frigatebird Fregata sp. cf. magnificens and of
   "Rosy-faced" type Lovebird Agapornis cf. roseicollis and the 3rd to 5th
   Golden Sparrow Passer luteus. Also noteworthy are the 6th of
   Green-winged Teal Anas carolinensis, of Bonaparte's Gull Chroicocephalus
   philadelphia, of Herring Gull Larus argentatus and of Snow Bunting
   Plectrophenax nivalis, the 7th to 9th of Yellow-browed Warbler
   Phylloscopus inornatus, the 9th of White-fronted Goose Anser albifrons,
   the 9th and 10th of Sabine's Gull Xema sabini, the 10th of Iceland Gull
   Larus glaucoides, the 11th and 12th of White-faced Storm-petrel
   Pelagodroma marina, the 12th of Red-breasted Flycatcher Ficedula parva
   and Balearic Woodchat Shrike Lanius senator badius, the 12th and 13th of
   Ring-necked Parakeet Psittacula krameri, the 13th and 14th of Brent
   Goose Branta bernicla, the 14th of Purple Sandpiper Calidris maritima,
   the 14th and 15th of Pectoral Sandpiper Calidris melanotos, the 17th of
   Black Vulture Aegypius monachus, the 17th to 20th of Glaucous Gull Larus
   hyperboreus, the 24th of Bluewinged Teal Anas discors and Fieldfare
   Turdus pilaris and the 24th and 25th of Red-footed Falcon Falco
   vespertinus.

DT Article
TI TAXONOMIC REVIEW OF THE GENUS LUCIOBARBUS HECKEL, 1843 (ACTINOPTERYGII,
   CYPRINIDAE) FROM NORTHWESTERN MOROCCO WITH THE DESCRIPTION OF THREE NEW
   SPECIES.
AU Casal-Lopez, Miriam
   Perea, Silvia
   Yahyaoui, Ahmed
   Doadrio, Ignacio (doadrio@mncn.csic.es) 
SO Graellsia
VL 71
IS 2
PS e027
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus Luciobarbus in Morocco presents high diversification, in
   contrast to the generally impoverished freshwater fish fauna from North
   Africa. Within Morocco the northern area is one of the least studied
   territories, due to both its historical background and the limited
   accessibility of many regions. Previous phylogenetic studies identified
   Luciobarbus populations that are morphologically and genetically
   differentiated, to the same extent as others already recognized as
   separate species. The aim of this work is to describe these populations
   as distinct species, based on morphological, meristic, and genetic
   traits.
C1 Doadrio, Ignacio; CSIC, Natl Museum Nat Sci, C Jose Gutierrez Abascal 2,
   Madrid, 28006, Spain, Spain.

PT J
AN ZOOR15203016968
DT Article
TI TWO NEW SPECIES OF ATLANTIC TROUT (ACTINOPTERYGII, SALMONIDAE) FROM
   MOROCCO.
AU Doadrio, Ignacio (doadrio@mncn.csic.es) 
   Perea, Silvia
   Yahyaoui, Ahmed
SO Graellsia
VL 71
IS 2
PS e031
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Four trout species of the genus Salmo Linnaeus, 1758 have been
   traditionally recognized in Morocco: S. macrostigma Dumeril, 1858; S.
   pallaryi Pellegrin, 1924; S. pellegrini Werner, 1931 and S. akairos
   Delling & Doadrio, 2005. Two of these species are mainly distributed in
   Mediterranean (S. macrostigma) and Atlantic (S. pellegrini) river basins
   while the other two species are restricted to isolated lakes in the
   Atlas Mountains, one of them to Ifni Lake (S. akairos) and the other,
   probably extinct, to Sidi Ali Lake (S. pallaryi). Preliminary
   phylo-genetic and regional studies based on molecular data have found
   high structuration of the populations of this genus in Morocco. These
   studies focused on allozymes, microsatellites and mitochondrial markers
   found genetic differences in populations from Isli Lake (Atlas
   Mountains) and the Draa Basin in southern Morocco. In this work we
   provide different morphological and genetic traits to distinguish these
   populations from Isli Lake and Draa Basin as two different species.
C1 Doadrio, Ignacio; CSIC, Museo Nacl Ciencias Nat, C Jose Gutierrez
   Abascal 2, Madrid, E-28006, Spain, Spain.
EM doadrio@mncn.csic.es

DT Article
TI Leptotyphlus (s. str.) siscoi sp. nov. from the pre-Pyrenees of
   Catalunya and Aragon (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae: Leptotyphlinae).
FT Leptotyphlus (s. str.) siscoi sp. nov. del Prepirineo catalano-aragones
   (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae: Leptotyphlinae).
AU Hernando, C. (leptotyphlus@gmail.com) 
SO Heteropterus Revista de Entomologia
VL 15
IS 2
PS 95-100
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of endogeous Staphylinidae, Leptotyphlus (s. str.) siscoi
   sp. nov., is described. The new species was found in the study of two
   Sierras from the pre-Pyrenees of Catalunya and Aragon: Serra de Lleras
   in the Noguera Pallaresa river valley (Lleida, Catalunya) and the spurs
   of Serra Caiba, in the river Esera valley (Huesca, Aragon). Both
   localities represent the first records of subfamily Leptotyphlinae for
   the province of Lleida and the Autonomous Community of Aragon
   respectively. The new species is included in the "pyrenaeus group"
   (sense Coiffait, 1972), and it is mainly characterised by the structure
   of the male genitalia. The taxonomic position of the new species is
   discussed and the morphological structures allowing its identification
   are figured. All specimens were collected with the combination of
   methods for soil washing and Berlese funnels.
C1 Hernando, C.; Apdo Correos 118, Badalona, Catalunya, E-08911, Spain,
   Spain.

TI Schizoptera (Lophopleurum) ribesi (Heteroptera: Schizopteridae), new
   species from Coiba Island National Park, Panama.
FT Schizoptera (Lophopleurum) ribesi (Heteroptera: Schizopteridae), nueva
   especie del Parque Nacional de la Isla de Coiba, Panama.
AU Costas, M. (costashemip@hotmail.com) 
   Lopez, T.
   Vazquez, M.A.
SO Heteropterus Revista de Entomologia
VL 15
IS 2
PS 101-109
PD 2015

LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB Schizoptera (Lophopleurum) ribesi sp. nov. (Heteroptera, Schizopteridae)
   is described from Coiba Island National Park (Panama). Morphological
   similarities and differences are analyzed with respect to the closest
   species. Scanning electron and optical photomicrographs and drawings are
   provided to illustrate most relevant morphological characters. A map of
   the Coiba Island National Park is also included, showing its geographic
   location as well as the sampling points where the new species was
   collected.

SO Heteropterus Revista de Entomologia

IS 2
PS 111-118
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB Chevrolatia sylvanica sp. nov. is described from southern Iberian
   Peninsula, belonging to the Chevrolatia insignis Jacquelin du Val, 1850
   species complex. The new species seems to be related to Chevrolatia hi:
   pc: Mat Franz, 1970, with which it shares the absence of a spiniform
   process in the male pro-trochanters. The two species can be clearly
   separated by the morphology of the aedeagus.

DT Article
TI A new species of the Genus Harpadon (Aulopiformes, Synodontidae) from
   the north-eastern Arabian Sea, India.
AU Ganga, U. (ganga@cmfri.org.in) 
   Thomas, Jinesh P.
   Sukumaran, Sandhya
SO Indian Journal of Fisheries
VL 62
IS 4
PS 1-9
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of Harpadon Lesueur, 1825 captured from the continental
   slope area 19[degree] 53' N - 69[degree] 23' E (north-eastern Arabian
   Sea) is described. The species Harpadon nudus sp. nov. was identified
   possessing a prominent trilobed caudal fin and a wide mouth with strong
   fang like barbed teeth and has been distinguished from its congeners by
   the following combination of characters: slender, completely scaleless
   body with very short pectoral (8.6 - 13.8% SL) and pelvic (16.4 - 21.6%
   SL) fins, large eyes (9.1 - 15.1% HL) with narrow inter-orbital width
   (15% of HL) and single pair of nares, situated close to the tip of the
   narrow snout. Morphologically it differs from the partially scaled
   species such as Harpadon nehereus in having very short pectoral fins not
   reaching up to its dorsal fin, single pair of nares and a pointed snout
   in dorsal view. It can be distinguished from Harpadon microchir by its
   greater head length of 22 - 26% SL; absence of scales at the base of the
   adipose fin and on the lateral line as well as the dorsal fin count of
   12 rays. It is differentiated from Harpadon mortenseni by its lower
   lateral line pores count (40 - 43), higher number of branchiostegals (17
   to 20), absence of scales on the lateral line or caudal peduncle and
   absence of vomerine teeth. It is distinct from Harpadon translucens
   which has a translucent body, partially covered with scales in the
   caudal region and protruding bristle like teeth on the jaw symphysis. It
   is distinguished from Harpadon squamosus which has scales on its head,
   trunk and caudal region with a relatively deeper body (5.8 in SL), by
   its slender and elongate body (8 - 10 in SL), short pelvic fins (16.4 -
   21.6% SL) not extending to the anal vent and a narrow snout. It is also
   distinguished from Harpadon erythraeus which has a dark body entirely
   covered with scales and black fins, short head and rounded snout. H.
   nudus sp. nov. stand apart from H. nehereus (Kimura 2 Parameter distance
   20%), the only species reported from the Arabian Sea and H. microchir
   (K2P 19%) by forming a distinct clade with 100% bootstrap support.
C1 Ganga, U.; ICAR Cent Marine Fisheries Res Inst, PB 1603,Ernakulam North
   PO, Kochi, Kerala, 682018, India, India.
EM ganga@cmfri.org.in
RI Sukumaran, Sandhya/R-4519-2019
SC Zoology
SN 0970-6011
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Marine zones; Indian
   Ocean; North Indian Ocean
DE Harpadon nudus [Arabian Sea / India / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Aulopiformes, Synodontidae
OR Harpadon - Lesueur 1825 (Synodontidae): [Diagnostic characters of
   subordinate taxa, P. 7]. 
   Harpadon nudus - Ganga & Jinesh 2015 (Synodontidae): [Sp nov, India
   (marine), P. 2]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15203018345
DA 2020-09-17

AN ZOOR15203017456
DT Article
TI Molecular phylogeny of the Taeniapterini (Diptera: Micropezidae) using
   nuclear and mitochondrial DNA, with a reclassification of the genus
   Taeniaptera Macquart.
AU Jackson, Morgan D. (morgandjackson@gmail.com) 
   Marshall, Stephen A.
   Skevington, Jeffrey H.
SO Insect Systematics & Evolution
VL 46
IS 5
PS 411-430
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB DNA molecular data are used to generate a phylogeny for the rnicropezid
   subfamily Taeniapterinae. Thirty-two taeniapterine species were sampled,
   including 10 of the 20 New World genera recognized by Steyskal, as well
   as one genus formerly treated as a synonym of Poeciloodus Hennig
   (Hemichaeta Steyskal). Five species from the Micropezinae were included
   as outgroups. A total DNA dataset of 4705 bp, including mitochondrial
   genes (12S and cytochrome c oxidase I (COI)) and nuclear coding genes
   (wingless and CAD), was analysed using maximum parsimony and Bayesian
   inference. The genus Taeniaptera Macquart was found to be
   non-monophyledc with respect to the remainder of the Taeniapterini
   analysed here. Taeniaptera is restricted to the Taeniaptera trivittata
   Macquart species group, Mitromyia Cresson is resurrected to contain the
   Deniaptera grata (Wulp) species group, and Paragrallomyia Hendel is
   resurrected to contain most species previously considered Taeniaptera.
   Poecilovlus is recognized as a paraphyledc group awaiting further
   research.
C1 Jackson, Morgan D.; Univ Guelph, Sch Environm Sci, Guelph, ON, N1G 2W1,
   Canada, Canada.
EM morgandjackson@gmail.com
SC Genetics &Heredity; Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1399-560X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic
   position; Status; Genetics; Evolution
DE Taeniapterini [Molecular genetics / mtDNA & nDNA sequences /
   systematics] [Phylogeny /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Flies
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Diptera, Brachycera, Cyclorrhapha,
   Micropezidae

DT Article
TI Phylogenetic analysis and redefinition of the maculata species group of
   Epicauta (Meloidae: Meloinae: Epicautini).
AU Paula Campos-Soldini, Maria (mariapaulacampos@gmail.com) 
   Sergio Alberto, Roig-Junent
SO Insect Systematics & Evolution
VL 46
IS 5
PS 431-470
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A cladistic analysis based on 81 morphological characters was performed
   in order to determine the phylogenetic relationships of 11 species of
   Epicauta from South America. We find that the 11 South American species
   constitute a monophyletic group together with all the North American
   species of the Epicauta maculates group. Within this clade, the 11
   species from South America conforms an apical monophyletic group within
   the E. maculates group. We propose to maintain the validity of the
   Epicauta maculata group, but also to redefine it with new characters.
   The South American species of the Epicauta maculata group are also
   described and illustrated. We propose the following nomenclatural
   changes: Epicauta rosilloi Martinez, junior synonym of Epicauta
   minutepunctata Borchmann; Epicauta fourcadei Denier, junior synonym of
   Epicauta fulvicornis (Burmeister), and Epicauta breyeri Denier, junior
   synonym of Epicauta nigropunctata Blanchard. We provide an
   identification key, new host plant associations, and updated geographic
   distribution.
C1 Paula Campos-Soldini, Maria; FCyT UADER, CICyTTP CONICET Mat & Espana,
   Diamante, Entre Rios, Argentina, Argentina.
EM mariapaulacampos@gmail.com
OI Campos-Soldini, Maria Paula/0000-0001-8228-4534

DT Article
TI New fossil wasps (Hymenoptera, Apocrita) from the Middle Jurassic of
   China.
AU Wang, Menglun
   Li, Longfeng (fenger4499@163.com) 
   Shih, Chungkun
SO Insect Systematics & Evolution
VL 46
IS 5
PS 471-484
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Two new species, Symphytopterus graciler sp. nov. of the family
   Ephialtitidae and Praeaulacus byssinus sp. nov. of the family
   Praeaulacidae, are described and illustrated from the late Middle
   Jurassic of Jiulongshan Formation at Daohugou in Inner Mongolia, China.
   Based on new information on S. graciler sp. nov. and P. byssinus sp.
   nov., two taxonomic keys to the known species of genera Symphytopterus
   and Praeaulacus are provided. By comparing the wings of Symphytopterus,
   we find that the change of the veins length is the main interspecific
   difference and S. liasinus may occupy the most basal position in
   Symphytopterus.
C1 Li, Longfeng; Capital Normal Univ, Coll Life Sci, 105 Xisanhuanbeilu,
   Beijing, 100048, China, China.
EM fenger4499@163.com

   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China; Europe; Geological time

DT Article
TI The earliest and most oriental Calvertiellidae unearthed
   (Palaeodictyoptera; Late Carboniferous; China).
AU Fu, Ying
   Bethoux, Olivier
   Yang, Qiang
   Ren, Dong (rendong@mail.cnu.edu.cn) 
SO Insect Systematics & Evolution
VL 46
IS 5
PS 485-492
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB We report the discovery of a new Calvertiellidae from the Xiaheyan
   locality (Namurian, early Late Carboniferous; Tupo Formation; China),
   namely Xiaheyanella orta gen. et sp. n. Besides representing both the
   most ancient and the most oriental occurrences for the family, the new
   species exhibits a derived wing venation pattern, especially if compared
   to the putative palaeodictyopteran cousins of the family. This discovery
   shows that, by the early Late Carboniferous, many insect lineages of
   moderate importance (i.e., considered at the familial level or below)
   already had a widespread distribution, and that derived conditions
   already accumulated. This concurs with the view that insects had already
   experienced a long evolutionary history by that time, remaining to be
   documented.
C1 Ren, Dong; Capital Normal Univ, Coll Life Sci, Xisanhuangbeilu 105,
   Beijing, 100048, China, China.
EM rendong@mail.cnu.edu.cn
RI Bethoux, Olivier/C-7308-2009
SC Zoology
SN 1399-560X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia; China; Geological time periods; Palaeozoic
DE Calvertiellidae [Oriental region /  / earliest record] [Carboniferous /
   Late Carboniferous / ]. 
   Xiaheyanella [Carboniferous /  / New genus]. 
   Xiaheyanella orta [Ningxia Hui /  / new species] [Carboniferous /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates

DT Article
TI Cladistic analysis of Indocryphalus Eggers (Coleoptera: Curculionidae:
   Scolytinae: Xyloterini) and description of a new species from Vietnam.
AU Cognato, Anthony I. (cognato@msu.edu) 
   Smith, Sarah M.
   Pham, Thai-H.
SO Insect Systematics & Evolution
VL 46
IS 5
PS 493-506
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB Indocryphalus suongmu sp. n. was described from northern Vietnam. A
   cladistic analysis of all nine species based on 22 morphological
   characters found I. suongmu and I. machili Wood as sister species.
   Species relationships, character evolution and patterns of
   ecology/geography were discussed in context of the cladogram. A
   modification of Beaver's (2000) key was presented to accommodate I.
   suongmu and I. machili. A new country record was reported for I.
   sordidus (Blandford).
C1 Cognato, Anthony I.; Michigan State Univ, Dept Entomol, 288 Farm Lane, E
   Lansing, MI, 48824, USA, USA.
EM cognato@msu.edu
RI Smith, Sarah/AAV-9484-2020
OI Smith, Sarah/0000-0002-5173-3736

   Sciences &Ecology

   morphology; Evolution; Ecology; Land zones; Oriental region; Palaearctic

   Cladistics / ] [Ecology /  / ] [Asia /  / distribution]. 
   Indocryphalus sordidus [Vietnam /  / New record]. 
   Indocryphalus suongmu [Vietnam /  / New species].

TI A new species of Paraberismyia Woodley (Diptera, Stratiomyidae,
   Beridinae) from Chiapas, Mexico.
AU Woodley, Norman E. (norman.woodley@ars.usda.gov) 
SO Insecta Mundi
VL 456
PS 1-6
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of Paraberismyia Woodley (Diptera, Stratiomyidae,
   Beridinae), P. imitator, n. sp., is described from Chiapas, Mexico. The
   new species is compared to previously described species and diagnostic
   notes are presented for separation of Paraberismyia from Berismyia
   Giglio-Tos.

TI Bolivian Cerambycinae: new anthophilous species (Coleoptera,
   Cerambycidae).
AU Clarke, Robin O.S. (hotelfandf@hotmail.com) 
SO Insecta Mundi
VL 453
PS 1-22
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English

AB New species of anthophilous Cerambycinae (Coleoptera, Cerambycidae) are
   described from Bolivia: Molorchini, Merionoedopsis zamalloae sp. nov.;
   Heteropsini, Chrysoprasis azurearegina sp. nov., and C. maryhowardae sp.
   nov.; Rhopalophorini, Dihammaphora densiserrata sp. nov., D. dilmanappae
   sp. nov., D. espinotibia sp. nov., D. fosterorum sp. nov., D.
   paraperforata sp. nov., D. pilcomayoensis sp. nov., and Rhopalophora
   santacruzensis sp. nov. All species are illustrated and host flower
   records are provided.

DT Article
TI A review of New World Laemophloeus Dejean (Coleoptera: Laemophloeidae):
   3. Nearctic species.
AU Thomas, Michael C. (michael.thomas@freshfromflorida.com) 
SO Insecta Mundi
VL 450
PS 1-35
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The nine Nearctic species of Laemophloeus Dejean (Coleoptera:
   Laemophloeidae) are reviewed, keyed, and illustrated. One species, L.
   apache Thomas, n. sp., is described as new. Two previously described
   species are synonymized: L. californicus Casey (= L. biguttatus (Say),
   n. syn.) and L. woodruffi Thomas (= L. fervidus Casey, n. syn.). A
   neotype is designated for L. biguttatus (Say), and lectotypes are
   designated for L. terminalis Casey and L. fervidus Casey. A checklist of
   the described world species is provided.
C1 Thomas, Michael C.; Florida State Collect Arthropods, Florida Dept Agr &
   Consumer Serv, POB 147100, Gainesville, FL, 32614, USA, USA.
EM michael.thomas@freshfromflorida.com
SC Zoology
SN 0749-6737; 1942-1354
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type material; Synonymy; Taxonomy;
   Key; Documentation; Publications; Land zones; Nearctic region; North
   America; USA

   to species] [ /  / Taxonomic review]. 
   Laemophloeus apache [Arizona /  / New species] [New Mexico /  / ] [Texas
   /  / ].

   2].

   P. 12].

DT Article
TI Description of Pallisentis (Brevitritospinus) punctati n. sp
   (Acanthocephala: Quadrigyridae) from Channa punctatus in Bareilly, Uttar
   Pradesh, India.
AU Gupta, Neelima (guptagrawal@rediffmail.com) 
   Gupta, Dileep K.
   Singhal, Priyanka
SO Iranian Journal of Parasitology
VL 10
IS 4
PS 605-616
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Background: The genus Pallisentis is an endoparasitic acanthocephalan
   inhabiting the intestinal walls. Hooks and spines of the worm are
   significant taxonomical and adaptive tools. Methods: The parasites were
   fixed, dehydrated and examined under Olympus BX 53 Microscope with DIC
   attachment, digital camera and CELLSENS imaging system (Light microscopy
   (LM)) and fixed in 2% glutaraldehyde in 0.1 M cacodylate buffer,
   dehydrated, rotary-coated with gold palladium in NeoCoater 100-240V and
   examined in Neo JCM-6000 (scanning electron microscopy (SEM)). Results:
   P. punctati n. sp. (prevalence 65.51%; mean intensity 3-6 par/host) is
   described. Females almost twice as large as males; proboscis hooks
   small; collar spine rows similar (16) and constant in both sexes but
   number of spines per row greater in females (22) than males (14); trunk
   spine rows 28-39 (spines per row 14-18) in females and 20-26 (spines per
   row 10-12) in males. spine length of females almost twice as long as
   males, spines extend up to posterior testis in males and 3/4 of total
   body length in females, Saefftigen. s pouch present, nuclei in cement
   gland 10-11, seminal vesicle, bursa and egg size small. SEM indicated
   lack of micro sculptures, and spines embedded on pre-trunk and trunk.
   Sex-based differences apparent (hook sizes, greater number of spines per
   row and longer spines in pre-trunk and trunk of females). Male trunk
   spine was narrower and of lateral spine with characteristic hooked
   appearance. Conclusion: A new species of Pallisentis based on LM and SEM
   is described, sexual diversity in hook and spine structure is reported.
C1 Gupta, Neelima; MJP Rohilkhand Univ, Dept Anim Sci, Bareilly, Uttar
   Pradesh, 243006, India, India.
EM guptagrawal@rediffmail.com
RI Gupta, Neelima/AAP-1879-2020
OI Gupta, Neelima/0000-0003-1523-5972
SC Zoology; Parasitology
SN 1735-7020
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Parasites diseases and disorders;
   Parasites; Helminth parasites; Hosts; Land zones; Oriental region;
   Eurasia; Asia; India
DE Channa punctatus [Acanthocephalan parasites / Pallisentis
   (Brevitritospinus) punctati / New parasite species] [Uttar Pradesh /  /
   New acanthocephalan parasite species]. 
   Pallisentis (Brevitritospinus) punctati [Piscean hosts / Channa
   punctatus / New parasite species] [Uttar Pradesh /  / New species from
   piscean host]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Invertebrates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Acanthocephala, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes,
   Actinopterygii, Perciformes, Channidae
OR Pallisentis (Brevitritospinus) punctati (Acanthocephala): [Sp nov, Uttar
   Pradesh, Parasite of Channa punctatus (Pisces), p. 607; Parasite]. 
   Channa punctatus (Channidae): [Host].

PT J
AN ZOOR15203016085
DT Article
TI A molecular phylogeny of bark spiders reveals new species from Africa
   and Madagascar (Araneae: Araneidae: Caerostris).
AU Gregoric, Matjaz (matjaz.gregoric@gmail.com) 
   Blackledge, Todd A.
   Agnarsson, Ingi
   Kuntner, Matjaz
SO Journal of Arachnology
VL 43
IS 3
PS 293-312
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 16
AB Bark spiders (genus Caerostris Thorell 1868) are important models in
   biomaterial research due to the remarkable biomechanical properties of
   the silk of C. darwini Kuntner & Agnarsson 2010 and its gigantic web.
   They also exhibit female gigantism and are promising candidates for
   coevolutionary research on sexual dimorphism. However, Caerostris
   spiders are taxonomically understudied and the lack of a phylogeny
   impedes evolutionary research. Using a combination of one mitochondrial
   and one nuclear marker, we provide the first species-level phylogeny of
   Caerostris including half of its species diversity but dense terminal
   sampling focusing on new lineages. Our phylogenetic and morphological
   results provide the evidence for six previously undescribed species: C.
   almae n. sp., C. bojani n. sp., C. pero n. sp. and C. wallacei n. sp.,
   all from Madagascar, C. linnaeus n. sp. from Mozambique and C. tinamaze
   n. sp. from the Republic of South Africa.
C1 Gregoric, Matjaz; Slovenian Acad Sci & Arts, Inst Biol, Novi Trg 2,POB
   306, Ljubljana, SI-1001, Slovenia, Slovenia.
EM matjaz.gregoric@gmail.com
RI Kuntner, Matjaz/AAE-2195-2020
SC Genetics &Heredity; Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 0161-8202
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Genetics; Evolution; Land zones;
   Afrotropical region; Africa
DE Caerostris [Molecular genetics / Mitochondrial & nuclear markers /
   taxonomic implications] [Phylogeny /  / ]. 
   Caerostris almae; Caerostris bojani; Caerostris pero; Caerostris
   wallacei [Madagascar /  / New species]. 
   Caerostris linnaeus [Mozambique /  / New species]. 
   Caerostris tinamaze [South Africa /  / New species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Araneae
OR Caerostris (Araneae). 
   Caerostris almae - Gregoric 2015 (Araneae): [Sp nov, Madagascar, P.
   298]. 
   Caerostris bojani - Gregoric 2015 (Araneae): [Sp nov, Madagascar, P.
   302]. 
   Caerostris linnaeus - Gregoric 2015 (Araneae): [Sp nov, Mozambique, P.
   303]. 
   Caerostris pero - Gregoric 2015 (Araneae): [Sp nov, Madagascar, P. 304].
   
   Caerostris tinamaze - Gregoric 2015 (Araneae): [Sp nov, South Africa, P.
   306]. 
   Caerostris wallacei (Araneae): [Sp nov, Madagascar, P. 307].

DT Article
TI On three new Euathlus tarantulas from Argentina and cladistic analysis
   of the genus.
AU Ferretti, Nelson (nferretti@conicet.gov.ar) 
SO Journal of Arachnology
VL 43
IS 3
PS 313-326
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Three unknown species of Euathlus Ausserer 1875 (Araneae: Theraphosidae)
   are recognized and formally described. Euathlus diamante Ferretti sp.
   nov., E. sagei Ferretti sp. nov., and E. tenebrarum Ferretti sp. nov.
   are described from the Mendoza and Neuquen provinces of western
   Argentina. The cladistic analysis showed Euathlus as monophyletic
   supported by the following synapomorphies: i) male tibial apophysis with
   fused branches bases; ii) presence of a ventral spine on retrolateral
   branch of male tibial apophysis; iii) sternum longer than wide.
   According to this cladistics analysis, a tree topology of (Homoeomma
   uruguayense (Mello-Leitao 1946) (Plesiopelma longisternale (Schiapelli &
   Gerschman 1942) (Grammostola anthracina (C.L. Koch 1842) (Phrixotrichus
   scrofa (Molina 1788) E. tenebrarum sp. nov. (E. truculentus L. Koch
   1875, E. sagei sp. nov. ((E. parvidus (Pocock 1903) (E. condorito
   Perafan & Perez-Miles 2014, E. manicata (Simon 1892), E. atacama Perafan
   & Perez-Miles 2014)) (E. antai Perafan & Perez-Miles 2014, E. diamante
   sp. nov.)))))))) is reported.
C1 Ferretti, Nelson; CCT CONICET La Plata, Ctr Estudios Parasitol &
   Vectores CEPAVE, Blvd 120 S-N E-61 & 62, La Plata, Buenos Aires,
   Argentina, Argentina.
EM nferretti@conicet.gov.ar

   region; South America

DT Article
TI Revised diagnoses for the pseudoscorpion genera Metawithius and
   Microwithius, with the description of a new Australian genus, and notes
   on Withius (Pseudoscorpiones, Withiidae).
AU Harvey, Mark S. (mark.harvey@museum.wa.gov.au) 
SO Journal of Arachnology
VL 43
IS 3
PS 353-370
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Pseudoscorpions of the family Withiidae are distributed in most regions
   of the world, but are less common in the Australian region. Apart from
   the cosmopolitan genus Withius Kew, 1911, the fauna is dominated by the
   endemic genera Metawithius Chamberlin, 1931 and Hyperwithius Beier,
   1951. A review of material of both genera reveals that Metawithius is a
   senior synonym of Hyperwithius, and is defined by the presence of a
   patch of rugose cuticle on the internal surface of the male maxilla. The
   genus contains the following taxa: M murrayi (Pocock, 1900), M
   philippinus Beier, 1937, M spiniventer Redikorzev, 1938, M. spiniventer
   pauper Beier, 1953, three species newly transferred from Hyperwithius to
   Metawithius, M annamensis (Redikorzev, 1938), comb. nov., M. tonkinensis
   (Beier, 1951), comb. nov. and M dawydoffi (Beier, 1951), comb. nov., and
   M. nepalensis (Beier, 1974) which is newly transferred from Withius. The
   remaining species previously attributed to Metawithius are transferred
   to other genera, primarily because they lack the patch of rugose
   cuticle. The subgenus Metawithius (Microwithius) Redikorzev, 1938 is
   once again raised to generic level, and provisionally contains four
   species, M yurii Redikorzev, 1938 from southeast Asia, and M. indicus
   (Murthy and Ananthakrishnan, 1977), comb. nov., M. chamundiensis
   (Sivaraman, 1980), comb. nov. and M. bulli (Sivaraman, 1980), comb. nov.
   from India. Metawithius ( Microwithius) tweediei Beier, 1955 also lacks
   the rugose patch of cuticle and is provisionally transferred to Withius,
   forming the new combination W tweediei (Beier, 1955). Two new species
   from northern Australian rainforests are found to be most similar to
   Metawithius but instead of an internal patch of rugose cuticle, they
   have an external patch. These new species, R. bulbosus sp. nov. (type
   species) and R. longissimus sp. nov., are placed in a new genus,
   Rugowithius. Afrowithius Chamberlin, 1931 is regarded as a new synonym
   of Withius, and the type species Chelifer paradoxus Ellingsen, 1912 from
   South Africa is treated as a senior synonym of Withius crassipes
   (Lawrence, 1937).
C1 Harvey, Mark S.; Western Australian Museum, Dept Terr Zool, Locked Bag
   49, Welshpool Dc, WA, 6986, Australia, Australia.
EM mark.harvey@museum.wa.gov.au
RI Harvey, Mark S/L-1177-2013; Harvey, Mark/P-4265-2019
OI Harvey, Mark S/0000-0003-1482-0109; Harvey, Mark/0000-0003-1482-0109

   Description; Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position;
   Status; Land zones; Australasian region; Australasia; Australia

   Rugowithius longissimus [Queensland /  / New species].

   Transferred from Afrowithius, p. 367; Syn nov, Withius crassipes
   (Lawrence 1937), p. 367]. 
   Withius tweediei - (Beier 1955) (Pseudoscorpionida): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Metawithius (Microwithius), p. 368].

DT Article
TI Fossil Platygastroidea in the National Museum of Natural History,
   Smithsonian Institution.
AU Talamas, Elijah J. (elijah.talamas@ars.usda.gov) 
   Buffington, Matthew L.
SO Journal of Hymenoptera Research
VL 47
PS 1-52
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Platygastroid wasps preserved in Dominican amber and oil shale from the
   Kishenehn formation (Montana, USA) in the National Museum of Natural
   History are catalogued. Compression fossils in Kishenehn oil shale yield
   a specimen of Fidiobia, a specimen of Telenominae, and a specimen with a
   Scelio-type ovipositor system. Twenty-five described genera are
   documented from Dominican amber, all of which are known from the extant
   fauna: Allostemma Masner & Huggert, Aradophagus Ashmead, Calliscelio
   Ashmead, Calotelea Westwood, Duta Nixon, Embidobia Ashmead, Embioctonus
   Masner, Fidiobia Ashmead, Gryon Haliday, Idris Forster, Inostemma
   Haliday, Leptacis Forster, Leptoteleia Kieffer, Macroteleia Kieffer,
   Odontacolus Kieffer, Opisthacantha Ashmead, Parabaeus Kieffer, Paridris
   Kieffer, Platygaster Latreille, Plaumannion Masner & Johnson,
   Probaryconus Kieffer, Psilanteris Kieffer, Spiniteleia Masner, Telenomus
   Haliday, and Triteleia Kieffer. Fourteen of these genera do not have
   previously published fossil records and are here documented for the
   first time. Plaumannion fistulosum Talamas, sp. n., and Paridris yumai
   Talamas, sp. n. are described as new species. A phylogenetic analysis of
   Paridris including P. yumai is presented. A male specimen belonging to
   an undescribed scelionine genus is documented and illustrated, but not
   described, as the best features for circumscribing this taxon are found
   in the female, and monographic work on this group is currently underway
   by other workers. Four specimens from Baltic amber, belonging to
   Leptacis, Platygaster, and Sembilanocera Brues are presented for
   comparison to extant specimens and inclusions in Dominican amber.
C1 Talamas, Elijah J.; ARS, Systemat Entomol Lab, Washington, DC, 20250,
   USA, USA.
EM elijah.talamas@ars.usda.gov
OI Buffington, Matthew/0000-0003-1900-3861; Talamas,
   Elijah/0000-0002-1048-6345
SC Zoology; Education &Educational Research; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1070-9428
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Animals and man; Education and
   entertainment; Documentation; Publications; Evolution; Land zones;
   Nearctic region; Neotropical region; North America; USA; Central

PT J
AN ZOOR15203017555
DT Article
TI Revision of the Rhopalomutillinae (Hymenoptera, Mutillidae): I, generic
   review with descriptions of three new genera.
AU Brothers, Denis J. (brothers@ukzn.ac.za) 
SO Journal of Hymenoptera Research
VL 46
PS 1-24
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The generic classification of the species of Rhopalomutillinae is
   reviewed and shown to comprise four distinct genera, three of which are
   described as new. All genera are known from both sexes and can be
   distinguished primarily on the basis of differences in the male
   genitalia and the female mesosomal form. A key is provided to the genera
   (Rimulotilla Brothers, gen. n.; Pherotilla Brothers, gen. n.;
   Rhopalomutilla Andre, 1901; Bischoffiella Brothers & Nonveiller, gen.
   n.) and they are each characterised and discussed. The already-described
   species are placed in the appropriate genera and the new combinations
   indicated: Ri. basalis (Bischoff, 1920), stat. n., comb. n.; Ri.
   conifera (Bischoff, 1920), comb. n.; Ri. tongaana (Peringuey, 1909),
   comb. n.; P. japhia (Cameron, 1902), comb. n.; P. mlanjeana (Bischoff,
   1920), comb. n.; P. oceanica (Mickel, 1935), comb. n.; P. rufitincta
   (Hammer, 1957), stat. n., comb. n.; P. striganovae (Lelej, 2012), comb.
   n.; B. cristata (Bingham, 1912), comb. n. In addition, Rh. javana
   Pagden, 1949, syn. n., is synonymized with P. oceanica (Mickel, 1935).
C1 Brothers, Denis J.; Univ KwaZulu Natal, Sch Life Sci, Private Bag X01,
   Pietermaritzburg, South Africa, South Africa.

DT Article
TI A rare ant on Samoa: first record of the cryptic subfamily Proceratiinae
   (Hymenoptera, Formicidae) and description of a new Proceratium Roger
   species.
AU Liu, Cong (cong.liu@oist.jp) 
   Fischer, Georg
   Economo, Evan P.
SO Journal of Hymenoptera Research
VL 46
PS 35-44
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 1
U2 1
AB In this study we present a taxonomic update for the Oceanian
   Proceratium. A recent ant biodiversity survey in Samoa collected an
   unknown Proceratium species, which we describe here as Proceratium
   silisili sp. n. This new species also presents the first record of this
   genus, as well as the whole subfamily Proceratiinae, in Samoa.
   Proceratium silisili is clearly distinguishable from the other Oceanian
   Proceratium species based on the differences in petiole node shape,
   number of mandible teeth, shape of the abdominal segment IV, as well as
   the surface sculpture on the head. A detailed description of P.
   silisili, high-quality specimen images, as well as an identification key
   to Oceanian species and a diagnostic discussion are provided.
C1 Liu, Cong; Okinawa Inst Sci & Technol Grad Univ, Kunigami, Okinawa,
   9040495, Japan, Japan.
EM cong.liu@oist.jp
RI Fischer, Georg/Y-3059-2019; Fischer, Georg/G-2484-2015; Liu,
   Cong/B-9927-2015
OI Fischer, Georg/0000-0002-4033-2005; Fischer, Georg/0000-0002-0637-6485;
   Liu, Cong/0000-0002-8664-6931
SC Zoology
SN 1070-9428
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones; Oceanic
   islands; Pacific Ocean islands
DE Proceratiinae [Samoa /  / New record]. 
   Proceratium [Oceanic islands /  / Key to species] [Samoa /  / New
   record]. 
   Proceratium silisili [Samoa /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hymenoptera, Apocrita, Aculeata,
   Formicoidea, Formicidae

   Proceratium silisili (Formicidae): [Sp nov, Samoa, P. 40].

AB Encarsia singhiellae Polaszek & Shih, sp. n., is described and
   illustrated. It is known so far from Taiwanand China. All specimens were
   reared from the ficus, or fig, whitefly Singhiella simplex (Singh), an
   Asian species recently attaining pest status in California, Colombia,
   and Florida.

   Braconidae), Doryctes (Neodoryctes) henanensis Li & van Achterberg, sp.

   Pterolophia sp. (Coleoptera: Cerambycidae), a twig-boring pest of
   Broussonetia papyrifera (L.) L'Hert. et Vent. (Moraceae), in Henan
   (Central China). A key to the Palaearctic species of the subgenus
   Neodoryctes is provided.

DT Article
TI Paracyphononyx scapulatus (Hymenoptera, Pompilidae), a koinobiont
   ectoparasitoid of Trochosa sp (Araneae, Lycosidae).
AU Souza, Hebert da Silva (hssouza.bio@gmail.com) 
   Messas, Yuri Fanchini
   Masago, Fabiana
   dos Santos, Eduardo Fernando
   Vasconcellos-Neto, Joao
SO Journal of Hymenoptera Research
VL 46
PS 165-172
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 9
AB The genus Paracyphononyx Gribodo, 1884 (Pompilidae) contains species
   that act as koinobiont parasitoids of cursorial spiders. Here, we record
   a new parasitism interaction involving the pompilid wasp Paracyphononyx
   scapulatus (Brethes) and the hunter spider Trochosa sp. (Lycosidae), and
   we describe how the wasp develops on the spider. This study contributes
   new information about the interaction between koinobiont ectoparasitoid
   wasps and spiders, which probably arose independently in different
   groups of wasps.
C1 Souza, Hebert da Silva; Univ Estadual Campinas, Inst Biol, Rua Monteiro
   Lobato 255, Sao Paulo, Brazil, Brazil.

TI Alburnus amirkabiri (Teleostei), a New Species of Shemaya from the Namak
   Lake Basin, Iran.
AU Mousavi-Sabet, H. (mousavi-sabet@guilan.ac.ir) 
   Vatandoust, S.
   Khataminejad, S.
   Eagderi, S.
   Abbasi, K.

   Vasil'eva, E.D.
SO Journal of Ichthyology
VL 55
IS 1
PS 40-52
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Alburnus amirkabiri, new species from the Namak Lake basin, Iran, is
   distinguished from the other Iranian species of Alburnus by the
   combination of characters, including poorly expressed fleshy ventral
   keel which extends up to 2[long dash]4 (usually 2) transverse scales
   rows counted from the anus forwards; 47[long dash]59 lateral line
   scales, 7[half][long dash]8[half] (usually 8[half]) branched dorsalfin
   rays, 10[half][long dash]12[half] (usually more than 10[half]) branched
   anal fin rays, 12[long dash]17 (usually 15[long dash]16) gill rakers,
   predorsal distance 50.0[long dash]54.4% SL, analfin base length 9.0[long
   dash] 11.7% SL, dorsalfin depth 16.7[long dash]20.9% SL, anal fin depth
   12.0[long dash]15.6% SL, body depth at dorsal fin origin 16.9[long
   dash]22.2% SL, caudal peduncle depth 8.7[long dash]10.4% SL, head depth
   62.2[long dash]71.9% head length, eye diameter 27.1[long dash]30.8% head
   length, dark lateral stripe on body.

PS 83-98

U1 0

AB Two new species of the euryphymine genus Phymeurus are described, one
   from Moroto Mountain, eastern Uganda (morotoensis n.sp.), and the other
   from West Central Tanzania, near Lake Tanganyika (kisuluensis n.sp.).
   The genus now contains 20 species, the majority in southern Africa.

PT J

DT Article
TI A cryptic new Potamanaxas (Hesperiidae: Pyrginae: Erynnini) stands out
   by terminally elongated genitalic valvae.
AU Grishin, Nick V. (grishin@chop.swmed.edu) 
   Janzen, Daniel H.
   Hallwachs, Winnie
SO Journal of Research on the Lepidoptera
VL 48
PS 13-20
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Potamanaxas louisghilli Grishin, sp. nov. is described from Area de
   Conservacion Guanacaste (ACG) in northwestern Costa Rica. Superficially,
   this species resembles several other Potamanaxas taxa with entire pale
   discal bands on the wings, but is distinguished from them by a row of
   faint postdiscal forewing spots (not streaks), terminally elongated
   genitalic valvae, and distinctive COI DNA barcodes. Found feeding on
   rain forest epiphytic Cavendishia axillaris and Psammisia ramiflora, the
   new species is likely to be host-specific to rain forest epiphytic
   Ericaceae, which are the food plants of all other known species of ACG
   Potamanaxas as well.
C1 Grishin, Nick V.; Univ Texas SW Med Ctr Dallas, Howard Hughes Med Inst,
   5323 Harry Hines Blvd, Dallas, TX, 75390, USA, USA.
EM grishin@chop.swmed.edu
SC Zoology
SN 0022-4324
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Neotropical region;
   Central America
DE Potamanaxas louisghilli [Costa Rica /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Papilionoidea, Hesperiidae

DT Article
TI A new species of Hypolycaena (Lepidoptera: Lycaenidae) from Arunachal
   Pradesh, north-eastern India.
AU Kunte, Krushnamegh (krushnamegh@ncbs.res.in) 
SO Journal of Research on the Lepidoptera
VL 48
PS 21-27
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species, Hypolycaena narada, sp. nov., is described from a series
   of male specimens from Arunachal Pradesh, north-eastern India. The new
   species is considerably distinct from other members of the tribe
   Hypolycaenini, and is easily distinguished from its relatives based on
   the following combination of characters: (a) slightly shining
   purple-blue upperside forewing with a dark, diffused androconial patch,
   (b) underside forewing apex and margin concolorous with the wing, (c)
   underside wings with narrow discal bands, ending in black costal spots,
   and (d) coastal black spot near the base.
C1 Kunte, Krushnamegh; Tata Inst Fundamental Res, Natl Ctr Biol Sci,
   Bellary Rd, Bengaluru, 560065, India, India.
EM krushnamegh@ncbs.res.in

PT J
AN ZOOR15203019055
DT Article
TI Two new species and taxonomic notes on species of Moeris Godman, 1900
   (Hesperiidae, Hesperiinae, Moncini).
AU Carneiro, Eduardo (carneiroeduardo@hotmail.com) 
   Mielke, Olaf H.H.
   Casagrande, Mirna M.
SO Journal of Research on the Lepidoptera
VL 48
PS 29-37
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Moeris Godman, 1900 was described to include two species, being
   afterwards combined with 10 additional species by Evans (1955). As the
   male genitalia of several Moncini species have been illustrated and
   described during recent decades, taxonomic rearrangements reduced the
   number of species in Moeris to four. In the present study two new
   species are described: Moeris seth Mielke, Carneiro & Casagrande sp.
   nov. from southern and southeastern Brazil, and Moeris nut Mielke,
   Carneiro & Casagrande sp. nov. from the Ecuadorian and Peruvian Andes.
   The status of Moeris menopis (Schaus, 1902) stat. rest. is revalidated;
   Moeris strada Evans, 1955 stat. nov. and Moeris stroma Evans, 1955 stat.
   nov. are elevated to species level; and a new combination of Mnasitheus
   submetallesces (Hayward, 1940) comb. nov. is proposed given the similar
   pattern of stigma, male and female genitalia to Mnasitheus Godman, 1900
   species, rather than with Moeris striga (Geyer, 1832), the type species
   of Moeris. Also, a neotype of Moeris striga and the lectotype of Moeris
   menopis are here designated in order to ascertain their taxonomic
   status. The female genitalia of the species studied are illustrated for
   the first time.
C1 Carneiro, Eduardo; Univ Fed Parana, Dept Zool, Caixa Postal 19020,
   Curitiba, Parana, BR-81531980 BC, Brazil, Brazil.
EM carneiroeduardo@hotmail.com
RI Mielke, Olaf H H/C-4986-2013; Carneiro, Eduardo/AAO-4991-2020;
   Casagrande, Mirna M/C-4590-2013
OI Mielke, Olaf H H/0000-0003-3655-4606; Carneiro,
   Eduardo/0000-0002-4796-0020; Casagrande, Mirna M/0000-0002-6076-8463

   Neotropical region; South America

   Moeris nut [Ecuador /  / New species] [Peru /  / ]. 
   Moeris seth [Brazil /  / New species].

   Papilionoidea, Hesperiidae

   figured, Female genitalia, p. 34]. 
   Mnasitheus submetallesces - (Hayward 1940) (Hesperiidae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Moeris, p. 36]. 
   Moeris - Godman 1900 (Hesperiidae). 
   Moeris menopis - (Schaus 1902) (Hesperiidae): [Lectotype designated, P.

   Brazil, P. 32].

   genitalia, p. 34; Raised from, Moeris striga strada, p. 36].

   Moeris striga menopis - (Schaus 1902) (Hesperiidae): [Raised to, Moeris
   menopis, p. 35, Cited by author as stat. rest.]. 
   Moeris striga strada - Evans 1955 (Hesperiidae): [Raised to, Moeris

   Moeris striga stroma - Evans 1955 (Hesperiidae): [Raised to, Moeris
   stroma, p. 36]. 
   Moeris stroma - Evans 1955 (Hesperiidae): [First time figured, Female
   genitalia, p. 34; Raised from, Moeris striga stroma, p. 36]. 
   Moeris submetallesces - Hayward 1940 (Hesperiidae): [Referred to,
   Mnasitheus, p. 36]. 
   Talides striga - Geyer 1832 (Hesperiidae): [Neotype designated, P. 30].

DT Article
TI Two new species of Euptychia Hubner 1818 (Lepidoptera: Nymphalidae:
   Satyrinae) from Mexico and Guatemala.
AU Nakahara, Shinichi (snakahara@ufl.edu) 
   Llorente-Bousquets, Jorge E.
   Luis-Martinez, Armando
   Miller, Jacqueline Y.
   Warren, Andrew D.
SO Journal of Research on the Lepidoptera
VL 48
PS 51-57
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species of Euptychia are described and illustrated from southern
   Mexico and Guatemala. Euptychia neblina A. Warren & Nakahara n. sp., is
   described from eleven specimens from cloud forest habitats in the
   Mexican states of Oaxaca and Chiapas, as well as Baja Verapaz,
   Guatemala. Euptychia lacandona A. Warren & Nakahara n. sp., is currently
   known from a single female specimen from Chiapas, Mexico. We discuss
   possible relationships between these two new species and other species
   of Euptychia.

TI A remarkable new Euptychia Hubner, 1818 (Lepidoptera: Nymphalidae:
   Satyrinae) from the Amazon basin of Peru and Colombia.
AU Nakahara, Shinichi (snakahara@ufl.edu) 
   Le Crom, Jean-Francois
   Lamas, Gerardo
SO Journal of Research on the Lepidoptera
VL 48
PS 59-63
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of Euptychia Hubner, 1818, from the Amazon basin of Peru
   and Colombia, E. juanjoi sp. nov., is described. This new species has a
   unique wing pattern compared to other members of the genus, but is
   placed in Euptychia due to the presence of a projection of the tegumen
   over the uncus in the male genitalia.

DT Article
TI Description of a new species of Myelobia Herrich-Schaffer (Lepidoptera,
   Pyralidae s.l., Crambinae) from Nicaragua feeding on cultivated bamboo,
   Guadua aculeata Rupr. ex E. Fourn. (Poaceae).
AU Landry, Bernard (bernard.landry@ville-ge.ch) 
   Maes, Jean-Michel
   Passoa, Steven C.
   Leger, Theo
SO Journal of Research on the Lepidoptera
VL 48
PS 65-81
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Myelobia nicaraguensis Landry & Maes, sp. n. was discovered in eastern
   Nicaragua. The caterpillar feeds on Guadua Aculeata Rupr. ex E. Fourn.
   (Poaceae). Brief biological notes and detailed descriptions of the
   adult, larva, and pupa are provided as well as part of the CO1 mtDNA
   barcode. This represents the first pupal description and the first
   detailed and illustrated description of the larva for the genus
   Myelobia. The immatures of M. nicaraguensis and M. smerintha are briefly
   compared and the systematic position of Myelobia within the Crambinae is
   also discussed.
C1 Landry, Bernard; Museum Hist Nat, CP 6434, Geneva, CH-1211, Switzerland,
   Switzerland.

DT Article
TI Description of a New Species of the Genus Troglophilus Krauss, 1879
   (Orthoptera: Rhaphidophoridae) from Northern Anatolia, Turkey.
AU Taylan, Mehmet Sait
   Mol, Abbas
   Sirin, Deniz (denizsirin19@gmail.com) 
SO Journal of the Entomological Research Society
VL 17
IS 2
PS 51-57
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB In this paper a new species of cave crickets Troglophilus (Orthoptera,
   Rhaphidophoridae) from northern Anatolia is described as Troglophilus
   aspegi Taylan and Sirin sp. nov.. Considering the other already
   recognised nine species in Anatolia, there are now total 10 species of
   Troglophilus that currently inhabit the caves and epigean habitats of
   Turkey. The new species is restricted to National Park of Kure Daglari
   in Bartin province and known only in one locality (Sipahiler cave).
   Troglophilus aspegi is morphologically distinguishable from the other
   nine Troglophilus species present in Turkey due to their small size,
   male tenth tergite, ovipositor shape, reddish-light brown body color.
   New species differs from the morphologically closest T tatyanae for body
   color, tenth tergite and epiphallus shape in male, subgenital plate
   shape in both sexes, length of the appendages and spinulation of the
   legs. On the other hand, these new data show that geographical
   distribution of Troglophilus is not only restricted with north eastern
   Anatolia but also in caves from north western section of Blacksea Region
   of Turkey.
C1 Sirin, Deniz; Namik Kemal Univ, Fac Art & Sci, Tekirdag, Turkey, Turkey.
EM denizsirin19@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 1302-0250
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia

   Troglophilus aspegi [Turkey /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Orthoptera, Saltatoria
OR Troglophilus (Saltatoria): [New record]. 
   Troglophilus aspegi - Taylan & Sirin 2015 (Saltatoria): [Sp nov, Turkey,
   P. 52].

AN ZOOR15203020261
DT Article
TI A new pygmy species of box jellyfish (Cubozoa: Chirodropida) from
   sub-tropical Australia.
AU Gershwin, Lisa-Ann (lisa-ann.gershwin@csiro.au) 
   Ekins, Merrick
SO Marine Biodiversity Records
VL 8
PS e111
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Tropical box jellyfish include some of the world's most venomous
   animals, leading researchers and the media to wonder whether changes in
   climate may drive these species into sub-tropical waters. The discovery,
   therefore, of small box jellyfish in the waterways of the Gold Coast and
   Sunshine Coast of south-east Queensland raised concern. This pygmy
   species proved to be new to science, separated from other species in the
   genus Chiropsella by its very small size; its semi-circular phacellae;
   very shallow, coalesced gastric saccules; its peculiar, long pedalia
   where the 'palm' is greatly reduced and the nonopposing 'fingers' branch
   off together at the same level; and a knee-like bend of the pedalial
   canal. The residential canal/river habitat of this species of
   chirodropid raises the question of whether this area is also suitable
   for habitation by the larger, more virulent chirodropids such as the
   so-called 'deadly box jellyfish', Chironex fleckeri. This new species,
   Chiropsella saxoni sp. nov., brings the total number of chirodropid
   species described from Australian waters to five.
C1 Gershwin, Lisa-Ann; CSIRO Marine & Atmospher Res, Hobart, Tas, 7000,
   Australia, Australia.
EM lisa-ann.gershwin@csiro.au
RI Gershwin, Lisa-ann/N-6392-2015; Ekins, Merrick/B-8256-2015
OI Gershwin, Lisa-ann/0000-0003-1254-725X; Ekins,
   Merrick/0000-0002-4825-462X
SC Zoology
SN 1755-2672
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Marine zones; Pacific
   Ocean
DE Chiropsella saxoni [South Pacific / Australia, Queensland / New
   species]. 
TN Coelenterates; Invertebrates

   subordinate taxa, P. 2].

   P. 2].

DT Article
TI Description of Stephos grieveae sp nov (Calanoida, Stephidae) from an
   anchialine cave in the Adriatic Sea.
AU Krsinic, Frano (fkrsinic@izor.hr) 
SO Marine Biodiversity Records
VL 8
PS e125
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of stephid calanoids copepod Stephos grieveae sp. nov. was
   collected from an anchialine cave on Mljet Island (Croatia). The new
   species can be distinguished from other Stephos spp. by a combination of
   the following features: last pedigerous somite slightly asymmetrical,
   female genital double-somite symmetrical in ventral view, about as long
   as wide, single operculum; antennules of both sexes are symmetrical,
   24-segmented and very long, reaching almost to end of anal somite;
   antennal exopod 7-segmented; maxillule displays 13 armature elements on
   praecoxal arthrite; female fifth legs symmetrical, uniramous and
   3-segmented, terminal segment very long armed with spinules distally
   along inner and outer margins, single small spine on anterior surface
   and spiniform process laterally; male fifth legs are uniramous and
   asymmetrically, right leg 4-segmented and left 5-segmented, segment 4
   not swollen and segment 5 simple, crescent shaped and is connected to
   segment 4 at approximately one quarter of its length. The shorter part
   of segment 5 tapers into a heavy process, while the longer part forms a
   club-shaped, curved extension.
C1 Krsinic, Frano; Inst Oceanog & Fisheries Split, Ivana Mestrovica 63,
   Split, HRV-21001, Croatia, Croatia.
EM fkrsinic@izor.hr
SC Zoology
SN 1755-2672
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Marine zones; Atlantic Ocean; North
   Atlantic
DE Stephos grieveae [Mediterranean Sea / Croatia / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Copepoda, Calanoida
OR Stephos grieveae (Calanoida): [Sp nov, Croatia (marine), P. 2].

AN ZOOR15203020267
DT Article
TI New records of 'opisthobranchs' (Gastropoda: Heterobranchia) from
   Arrecife Alacranes National Park, Yucatan, Mexico.
AU Ortigosa, Deneb (deneb.ortigosa@gmail.com) 
   Lemus-Santana, Elia
   Simoes, Nuno
SO Marine Biodiversity Records
VL 8
PS e117
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB We report 37 species of heterobranch sea slugs from the National Park
   Alacranes reef, located in the Campeche Bank, at the south-eastern Gulf
   of Mexico, of which 18 species are reported for the first time in this
   reef. With this contribution, the species richness in this national park
   increases to up to 67. The species Nakamigawaia felis, Petalifera sp.,
   Elysia flava, Elysia pratensis and Bulbaeolidia sp. are reported in the
   Gulf of Mexico for the first time. The geographical distribution ranges
   for Oxynoe azuropunctata, Elysia ornata, Placida kingstoni, Aphelodoris
   antillensis and Tritonia hamnerorum are extended westward. Those for
   Elysia flava, Pleurobranchus areolatus and Felimare ruthae are extended
   both northward and westward.
C1 Ortigosa, Deneb; Univ Nacl Autonoma Mexico, UMDI Sisal, Apdo 70-153,
   Mexico City, DF, 04510, Mexico, Mexico.
EM deneb.ortigosa@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 1755-2672

   [Gulf of Mexico /  / New record].

PT J
AN ZOOR15203017524
DT Article
TI Halearcturus, a new genus of Antarcturidae Poore, 2001 (Crustacea:
   Isopoda: Valvifera) with a key to genera of the family.
AU Poore, Gary C.B. (gpoore@museum.vic.gov.au) 
SO Memoirs of Museum Victoria
VL 73
PS 13-18
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new genus Haleurcturus is erected for a single species, Arcturus
   serrulatus Whitelegge, 1904. It differs from all other antarcturid
   genera in the combination of having an antennal flagellum of one major
   article plus a short curved tapering article (all other genera have
   either three or four articles, or about nine, plus a terminal one) and
   is unusual in lacking a uropodal exopod. Halearcturus has unique complex
   ornamentation; it lacks both a strong medial posterior spine and a pair
   of prominent sublateral spines on the pleotelson, typical of other
   antarcturids. The genus has a single species from south-eastern
   Australia. A key to genera of Antarcturidae is presented.
C1 Poore, Gary C.B.; Museum Victoria, GPO Box 666, Melbourne, Vic, 3000,
   Australia, Australia.
EM gpoore@museum.vic.gov.au
SC Zoology
SN 1447-2546; 1447-2554
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Description;
   Combination; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Key
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Malacostraca, Eumalacostraca,
   Peracarida, Isopoda
OR Antarcturidae - Poore 2001 (Isopoda): [Key to genera, P. 13]. 
   Arcturus serrulatus - Whitelegge 1904 (Isopoda): [Designated type
   species for new genus, Halearcturus, p. 14]. 
   Halearcturus (Isopoda): [Gen nov, Of family Antarcturidae, Type species
   Arcturus serrulatus Whitelegge 1904, p. 14]. 
   Halearcturus serrulatus - (Whitelegge 1904) (Isopoda): [Redescription,
   P. 15; Comb nov, Transferred from Microarcturus, p. 15]. 
   Microarcturus serrulatus - (Whitelegge 1904) (Isopoda): [Referred to,
   New genus Halearcturus, p. 15].

TI New asterinid seastars from northwest Australia, with a revised key to
   Aquilonastra species (Echinodermata: Asteroidea).
AU O'Loughlin, P. Mark (pmoloughlin@edmundrice.org) 
   Bribiesca-Contreras, Guadalupe
SO Memoirs of Museum Victoria
VL 73
PS 27-40
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Woodside/Western Australian Museum Kimberley Project 2008-2015
   collected four small asterinid seastar specimens from Cassini Island and
   Long Reef in the Kimberley region of north Western Australia. The
   specimens are lodged in the Western Australian Museum. They represent
   two new species of Aquilonastra O'Loughlin: Aquilonastra alisonae sp.
   nov.; Aquilonastra cassini sp. nov. An updated key is provided for
   species assigned to Aquilonastra, and a table distinguishing
   Aquilonastra species from the Kimberley region.

TI Enigmatic ophiuroids from the New Caledonian region.
AU O'Hara, Timothy D. (tohara@museum.vic.gov.au) 
   Harding, Caroline
SO Memoirs of Museum Victoria
VL 73
PS 47-57
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Three new species are described from New Caledonia which have been
   provisionally placed in the genera Ophiohamus (Ophiacanthidae),
   Ophionereis (Ophionereididae) and Ophiodaphne (Amphiuridae)
   respectively, pending a comprehensive revision of the Ophiuroidea. In
   addition, new specimens and morphological variation is described for the
   species Amphipholis linopneusti (Amphiuridae). Our knowledge of the
   deep-sea fauna of New Caledonia remains incomplete.

PT J
AN ZOOR15203017529
DT Article
TI Sea cucumbers of the Kerguelen Plateau, with descriptions of new genus
   and species (Echinodermata: Holothuroidea).
AU O'Loughlin, P. Mark (pmoloughlin@edmundrice.org) 
   Skarbnik-Lopez, Jessica
   Mackenzie, Melanie
   VandenSpiegel, Didier
SO Memoirs of Museum Victoria
VL 73
PS 59-93
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new genus of holothuroid, Calcamariina O'Loughlin, and five new
   species of holothuroids. with authors O'Loughlin & Skarbnik-Lopez, from
   near Heard and McDonald Islands on the Kerguelen Plateau in the Southern
   Ocean are described: Calcamariina hibberdi, Calcamariina moorea,
   Echinocucumis ampla, Psolus heardi, Paracaudina championi. The new
   species Paracaudina championi has the diagnostic characters of both
   Paracaudina Heding and Hedingia Deichmann. Molpadia violacea Studer is
   raised out of synonymy with Molpadia musculus Risso. Molpadia violacea
   is reviewed, and an extended distribution around Antarctica is proposed.
   The distribution of Molpadia magdae O'Loughlin (in O'Loughlin et al.) is
   extended from the South Shetland Islands to Prydz Bay. Pseudopsolus
   macquariensis forma gruai Cherbonnier & Guille is raised to species
   status. Laevocnus O'Loughlin (in O'Loughlin et al.) is an objective
   junior synonym of Pentactella Verrill. A sensu stricto diagnosis is
   provided for Pentactella. The always smaller, brood-protecting Psolus
   ephippifer Thomson specimens may be juveniles of the sympatric and
   always larger, non-brooding, Psolus paradubiosus Carriol & Feral
   specimens. Comprehensive lists are provided for all holothuroids that
   have been reported from the vicinity of Heard and McDonald Islands, and
   for the Kerguelen Plateau. Individual lists are provided for all
   holothuroid specimens from the vicinity of Heard and McDonald Islands
   that are held in Museum Victoria. the South Australian Museum, and the
   Tasmanian Museum and Art Gallery. Holothuroid species variably common to
   the Kerguelen Plateau, coast of Antarctica, Macquarie Island, Magellanic
   Region and Bouvetoya Island are listed.
C1 O'Loughlin, P. Mark; Museum Victoria, Marine Biol Sect, GPO Box 666,
   Melbourne, Vic, 3001, Australia, Australia.
EM pmoloughlin@edmundrice.org
SC Zoology
SN 1447-2546; 1447-2554
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Status;
   Documentation; Publications; Marine zones; Indian Ocean
DE Calcamariina hibberdi; Calcamariina moorea; Echinocucumis ampla;
   Paracaudina championi; Psolus heardi [South Indian Ocean / Heard Island
   and McDonald Islands / New species]. 
   Holothuroidea [Checklists /  / ] [South Indian Ocean / Heard & McDonald
   Islands / ] [ / Kerguelen Plateau / Systematics]. 
   Molpadia magdae [Antarctic Ocean / Antarctica, Prydz Bay / New record]. 
TN Echinoderms; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Echinodermata, Holothuroidea
OR Holothuroidea (Echinodermata). 
   Calcamariina - O'Loughlin 2015 (Holothuroidea): [Gen nov, Of subfamily
   Cucumariinae, Type species Calcamariina hibberdi O'Loughlin &
   Skarbnik-Lopez 2015, p. 61]. 
   Calcamariina hibberdi - O'Loughlin & Skarbnik-Lopez 2015
   (Holothuroidea): [Sp nov, Heard Island and McDonald Islands (marine), P.
   61]. 
   Calcamariina moorea - O'Loughlin & Skarbnik-Lopez 2015 (Holothuroidea):
   [Sp nov, Heard Island and McDonald Islands (marine), P. 75]. 
   Echinocucumis ampla - O'Loughlin & Skarbnik-Lopez 2015 (Holothuroidea):
   [Sp nov, Heard Island and McDonald Islands (marine), P. 77]. 
   Molpadia magdae (Holothuroidea): [New record]. 
   Molpadia musculus - Risso 1826 (Holothuroidea): [Removal from synonymy,
   Molpadia violacea Studer 1876, p. 90]. 
   Molpadia violacea - Studer 1876 (Holothuroidea): [Removal from synonymy,
   With Molpadia musculus Risso 1826, p. 90]. 
   Paracaudina championi - O'Loughlin & Skarbnik-Lopez 2015
   (Holothuroidea): [Sp nov, Heard Island and McDonald Islands (marine), P.
   84]. 
   Pentactella - Verrill 1876 (Holothuroidea): [Diagnosis, P. 80; Syn nov,
   Laevocnus O'Loughlin 2014, p. 80; Syn nov, Pseudocnus Panning 1949, p.
   80; Removal from synonymy, With Stereoderma Ayres 1851, p. 80]. 
   Pseudopsolus gruai - Cherbonnier & Guille 1975 (Holothuroidea): [Raised
   from, Pseudopsolus macquariensis form. gruai, p. 91]. 
   Pseudopsolus macquariensis form. gruai - Cherbonnier & Guille 1975
   (Holothuroidea): [Raised to, Pseudopsolus gruai, p. 91]. 
   Psolus heardi - O'Loughlin & Skarbnik-Lopez 2015 (Holothuroidea): [Sp
   nov, Heard Island and McDonald Islands (marine), P. 81]. 
   Stereoderma - Ayres 1851 (Holothuroidea): [Removal from synonymy,
   Pentactella Verrill 1876, p. 80].

PT J
AN ZOOR15203017530
DT Article
TI Micheleidae (Crustacea: Decapoda: Axiidea): new family, generic and
   species synonymies, three new Australian species, and new records.
AU Poore, Gary C.B. (gpoore@museum.vic.gov.au) 
   Collins, David J.
SO Memoirs of Museum Victoria
VL 73
PS 95-105
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Micheleidae are shown to include all taxa previously separated as
   Meticonaxiidae. A revised key to genera, Marcusiaxius, Meticonaxius,
   Tethisea and Michelea is presented. Meteoraxius Sakai and Turkay, 2012
   is synonymised with Meticonaxius de Man, 1905. Micheleopsis Sakai, 2010
   is synonymised with Michelea Kensley and Heard, 1991; among other quite
   trivial differences, the genus had been differentiated on a simple form
   of the male pleopod 1, suspected to be a juvenile feature and/or lacking
   merit as a generic character. Three new species, Michelea kalbarri, M.
   imperieusae and Tethisea alanwilliamsi are described. Michelea kalbarri
   is unique in its genus in lacking pleopodal lamellae. Michelea
   novaecaledoniae Poore, 1997 is added to the Australian fauna. Michelea
   paraleura is synonymised with M. leura.
C1 Poore, Gary C.B.; Museum Victoria, GPO Box 666, Melbourne, Vic, 3001,
   Australia, Australia.
EM gpoore@museum.vic.gov.au
SC Zoology
SN 1447-2546; 1447-2554

   Taxonomic position; Key; Marine zones; Indian Ocean; Pacific Ocean

   Indian Ocean / Australia, Western Australia / New species]. 
   Michelea novaecaledoniae [South Pacific / Australia / New record]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Malacostraca, Eumalacostraca, Eucarida,
   Decapoda, Reptantia, Anomura
OR Meticonaxius - de Man 1905 (Anomura): [Syn nov, Meteoraxius Sakai &
   Tuerkay 2012, p. 97]. 
   Michelea - Kensley & Heard 1991 (Anomura): [Syn nov, Micheleopsis Sakai
   2010, p. 97]. 
   Michelea imperieusae (Anomura): [Sp nov, Australia, Western Australia
   (marine), P. 98]. 
   Michelea kalbarri (Anomura): [Sp nov, Australia, Western Australia
   (marine), P. 98]. 
   Michelea leura - Poore & Griffin 1979 (Anomura): [Syn nov, Michelea
   paraleura Poore 1997, p. 101]. 
   Michelea novaecaledoniae (Anomura): [New record]. 
   Michelea orlik - (Sakai 2010) (Anomura): [Referred to, Micheleopsis, p.
   97]. 
   Micheleidae - Sakai 1992 (Anomura): [Syn nov, Meticonaxiidae Sakai 1992,

AB Echinodera (Ruteria) soumasi sp. n. is described from Epirus and the

TI Three new species of long-legged flies (Diptera, Dolichopodidae) for the
   Swiss fauna.
FT Drei neue Arten der Langbeinfliegen (Diptera, Dolichopodidae) fur die
   Schweizer Fauna.

VL 88

LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB Chrysotus collini Parent, 1923, Dolichopus arbustorum Stannius, 1831 and
   Dolichopus cilifemoratus Macquart, 1827 are recorded for the first time
   for Switzerland. Dolichopus occultus Becker, 1917 is proposed as new
   synonym of Dolichopus arbustorum. The male genitalia of Chrysotus
   collini, Chrysotus gramineus (Fallen, 1823) and Chusotus angulicornis
   Kowarz, 1874 are figured.

TI Faunistical data of Carnidae (Diptera) from Switzerland and additional
   countries with the description of three new Meoneura species.
AU Stuke, Jens-Hermann (jstuke@zfn.uni-bremen.de) 
   Baechli, Gerhard
SO Mitteilungen der Schweizerischen Entomologischen Gesellschaft
VL 88
IS 3-4
PS 379-401
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The previously unidentified Carnidae from the collection of Gerhard
   Bachli have been investigated. All in all, faunistical records of 26
   species from Switzerland are presented. Meoneura alphabetica
   Carles-Tolra & Ventura, 2002, Meoneura exigua Collin, 1930, Meonettra
   milleri Gregor, 1973, Meoneura moravica Gregor & Papp, 1981, and
   Meoneura obscurella (Fallen, 1823) are new for the fauna of Switzerland.
   Meoneura occulta spec. nov., Meoneura pappi spec. nov., and Meoneura
   ziegleri spec. nov. are described. Additional records of Carnidae are
   reported from Austria, Canada, Czech Republic, Egypt, France, Germany,
   Iran, Italy, Liechtenstein, Montenegro, Norway, Serbia, and the USA.

DT Article
TI Urubicimbera, a new Orthocladiinae genus from Brazil (Diptera,
   Chironomidae).
AU Andersen, Trond (trond.andersen@uib.no) 
   Mendes, Humberto Fonseca
   Pinho, Luiz Carlos
SO Norwegian Journal of Entomology
VL 62
IS 2
PS 160-166
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Urubicimbera n. gen. is erected based on the male of U. montana n. sp.
   from Santa Catarina State in South Brazil. The genus can be separated
   from other Orthocladiinae genera based on the combination of bare eyes,
   wing and squama; low antennal ratio (AR <= 0.3), antenna with apical
   seta; no acrostichals; costa short, ending at < 0.6 of wing length; with
   long, false vein nearly reaching wing tip; R4+5 ending proximal to M3+4;
   anal point long, narrowly triangular, evenly tapering to pointed apex,
   with microtrichia only and virga composed of single, stout spine.
C1 Andersen, Trond; Univ Bergen, Univ Museum Bergen, POB 7800, Bergen,
   NO-5020, Norway, Norway.
EM trond.andersen@uib.no
SC Zoology
SN 1501-8415

   South America

TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Flies
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Diptera, Nematocera, Chironomidae

   species Urubicimbera montana, p. 161]. 
   Urubicimbera montana (Chironomidae): [Sp nov, Brazil, P. 162].

TI Systasis edlandi - a new species of Ormocerinae (Hymenoptera,
   Pteromalidae) from Norway associated with rowan berry (Sorbus aucuparia)
   (Rosaceae).
AU Thuroczy, Csaba K. (thuroczy.cs@freemail.hu) 
   Hansen, Lars Ove
SO Norwegian Journal of Entomology
VL 62
IS 2
PS 205-209
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Systasis edlandi n. sp. is described from Norway, representing a new
   species of Systasis Walker, 1834. Discrimination from the closest
   species is discussed briefly. The material is a result of an extensive
   hatching project from rowan berry (Sorbus aucuparia) run by the late
   Torgeir Edland. Even though the exact circumstances about the biology
   can be recalled, it is to believe that the host is a gall midge
   (Diptera, Cecidomyiidae).
